I have been a bankrupt, and am proud to boast I have paid 20s. in the pound - I was a bankrupt twenty-two years ago - I was one but a year ago, and lost 22,000l. - I have been a bankrupt four times, but always paid 20s. in the pound - I have never compounded with my creditors or taken the benefit of the Act - I never superseded either of the commissions - I have been plundered of too much money - there was 3,000l. to pay 1,000l. - I have been convicted of a conspiracy - I beg to state it was through the attorney who is now conducting the defence, Saul Yates, of Bury-street - it was in consequence of his swearing he saw placards in the hands of myself, and the other party, when we had ten respectable witnesses - we have a rule nisi granted for a new trial, on the perjury of Mr. Yates.

Q. Among the rest of your misfortunes, how often have you been burnt out and recovered the money from the offices? A. I never recovered money but once - when my wife was nearly burnt to death, I received 70l., and my costs were 200l. - I have had fires in my factory when I was not insured for a farthing, and lost 1,000l. - I think fires have occurred accidentally at my manufactory three times, but I was not insured for 1s. - I never swore that I once received 70l., and at another time 100l. - I think about eighteen years ago there was a sum of 110l., and 70l. when my wife was nearly burnt to death - it was not 200l. that I said I recovered - to my knowledge I never said so - I cannot tell what I said three or four years ago.
Q. Did you not say that you recovered 90l. once, and 200l. at another time? A. I cannot say that I did - I will not say I did not.

Q. Pray did you ever indict a gentleman named Jessop, or something, for perjury? A. Yes; there have been indictments and cross indictments and informations, and 1,000l. has been spent in law expenses.

Q. When you prosecuted that person, did not the Jury stop the case in the middle, and declare themselves satisfied? A. I suppose they were satisfied - there have been complete cross indictments - it was on the 27th of June that my son and I were at the Bank Coffee-house - my son, I believe, saw the prisoner a week afterwards - I was not present - I made application to him by letter, I think, on the 1st ofAugust - I expected the watch was the same as my bill, that all he had told me about his wife's aunt and the property was as true as could be - the bill was due on the 31st of July - I then found it was worth nothing - I applied to the magistrate about eight or ten days after, at Lambeth-street - I think, the prisoner was held to bail - fully committed - he was not held to bail at Lambeth-street - he was fully committed, that I swear - I went to Guildhall, I believe, two or three days after, for we found out the occurrence took place in the City, and could not be entertained - the Lambeth-street magistrate did not tell me that he had no jurisdiction - if your client has told you so, it is false; if my son said so, it must not be with any intention, but a mistake - I mentioned, on my examination before the magistrate, at Lambeth-street, that he obtained a gold watch to show Mr. Alexander, and at Guildhall, before Alderman Copeland.

Q. Did you get to the Mansion-house before the 26th of August? A. I really cannot tell - I went myself and took the prisoner about the bill on Wednesday morning, for we could not find him at home - I took him first on the Bill of Exchange - the Bill of Exchange was given for part money he owed me two years ago, and 25l. cash - I discounted a bill of 15l. brought to me by Mr. Tibbins - it was never paid, and both parties were sued on it - the prisoner called, and said he was a poor man, and it was useless my going against him - I let it go against Tibbins - my expenses were 10l.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. The affair of the bill is the subject of a future indictment? A. Yes: I have indicted him for fraud respecting that transaction - that bill has nothing to do with the watch - my son has never been burnt out at any time, nor a bankrupt.
Q. Did you, or your son in your presence, on your oath, give him any authority whatever to dispose of or pawn the watch? A. Certainly not.

WILLIAM KING
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in High Holborn - I do not know the prisoner - I did not take the watch in myself - I was subpoened here to produce it - the person who took it in is not here - how the watch came into my house I do not know - I have the counterpart of the duplicate - it was pawned on the 18th of July in the name of Samuel Wilkins, with the prisoner's right address - the duplicate the officer has is the counterpart of the one on the watch.

JAMES LEE
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street - I found the duplicate in the prisoner's pocket-book - I apprehended him on the 17th of August - he acknowledged, in the presence of the prosecutor, that it was the duplicate of the watch he had from him - I apprehended the prisoner on another charge.

Cross-examined. Q. He pawned it in his right name and place of abode? A. Yes: I found him at that place - I did not know him before - I was not applied to to look after him till the Saturday - I was present at the examination at Lambeth-street - the watch was mentioned there.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was not the examination at Lambeth-street taken down in writing? A. No: he was remanded to the Mansion-house.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What charge was he examined on? A. First on a charge of forgery, it was then considered to be fraud - Mr. Norton, the solicitor, discovered on Tuesday that the offence was committed in the City - he was not committed from our office - he was remanded to the Mansion-house - I took him there on the Thursday, I think to Guildhall; and to the Mansion-house, on the 26th - he was not committed for the bill - the bill was mentioned - Mr. Norton attended as attorney for the prosecution, at both examinations.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has the prisoner an attorney? A. Yes - the Bill of Exchange and the watch are two different transactions, and form two separate indictments.
CHARLES MILLINGEN re-examined. This is my watch - I never gave him any authority to sell or dispose of it in any way - he promised to return it to me.
Cross-examined. Q. Was the watch finished when it went out of your hands? A. I am not in the trade - it is one I wear myself - I had worn it six months.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did it go like another watch? A. Yes - I wound it up regularly.

(The prisoner, in his defence, made a long address, which was partly inaudible: the substance was - that the charge was supported by gross perjury - that, in 1831, Millingen, sen., held a bill for 15l., accepted by the prisoner, and drawn by one Tibbins, which bill was given in consequence of some proceedings in the Insolvent Debtors' Court; the bill was dishonoured, Tibbins took the benefit of the Insolvent Act, but gave Millingen another bill for the one in question, and Millingen informed the prisoner he was exonerated from all liability on the bill - that he met Millingen the Bank Coffee-house, on the 27th of June, by appointment, having asked him to discount a £50 bill: which Millingen proposed to do, by giving £20 cash, selling the watch for 15l., and taking 15l. to pay Tibbins's bill - the prisoner objected to purchase the watch, and declined the proposal; Milligen then offered 25l. cash, to charge 10l. for the watch, to take 15l. for Tibbins's bill, and the prisoner's I O U for 14l. 15s., which included a sum of 9l. for costs incurred on Tibbis's bill; this was acceded to, and the prosecutor made no application to him to return the watch, nor did he charge him with stealing it till after he found he could not substantiate a charge of forgery against him.)
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. - Tuesday, September 9th.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1403.
THOMAS HATCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of June , 1 bugle, value 23s. ; the goods of
William John Longer
.

WILLIAM JOHN LONGER. I live in the Old Artillery Ground
. On the 17th of June, I lost this bugle from the door - I am a salesman - I saw it at Worship-street.

WILLIAM HEBERT
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. This bugle was pawned by William Willis.

WILLIAM WILLIS
. On the 17th of June, I was in Spitalfields - the prisoner came and asked me if I would buy a bugle - I said I did not particularly want it - I asked if it was a good one - he said, "Yes," and asked 15s. for it - I bought it for 14s. - I paid 9s. as a deposit - I afterwards pawned it at Hebert's.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is thevalue of this? A. About 16s - I am a musician - I have one which cost four guineas - there is no maker's name on this - I pawned it three or four hours after I bought it - I am not in the habit of buying things in the street - I was taken up, and gave every information - I know this is the same instrument; the bridge is off - you cannot play it without a bridge - I was going to have one put on - I teach the key bugle - I had to pawn one of my own instruments to buy this - I have scholars who learn of me - I was playing with two musicians when I bought this, neither of them are here - it was about eleven o'clock - I sounded it in the street - I found I could not play upon it - it was hung up in Mrs. Moffat's bar till I paid the other 5s.

Prisoner's Defence. I went down Petticoat-lane, and met a man who had a lot of cloth and this bugle-horn - he offered me the whole for 2l. - I gave him 30s. - I took it home, and made the cloth into caps, and hung the horn in my window, but could not sell it - I then saw this man playing, and asked him if he would buy it - I left the horn at Mrs. Moffat's for him - the next day she told me that the officer had been making inquiries for me - I went to the office, and saw Atfield - I asked him if he had been making inquiries for me - he asked me my name, and said, yes, he had.

HARRIET MOFFAT
. I keep the Crown public-house. The prisoner and the witness came to my house, and made their bargain, and they asked me to keep this horn till the witness brought 5s.
NOT GUILTY .

1404.
ANN MURRAY
and
SUSANNAH FURMERY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 sheet, value 1s.; 1 table-cloth, value 4s.; 1 pinafore, value 1s.; 3 aprons, value 1s. 6d.; 1 towel, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Hunt
; 3 bed-gowns, value 1s.; 3 pinafores, value 6d.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 1s. 6d.; 2 petticoats, value 6d.; one frock, value 1s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; and 3 aprons, value 1s.; the goods of
Edward Croft
; and, that Ann Murray had been before convicted of felony .

HENRIETTA PENDRELL
. I live in Grey's-buildings, Manchester-square
, and keep a mangle - the prisoner Murray had been a lodger of mine, but I had not seen her for nine or ten years - on the 12th of July, she came into my front kitchen - I was in the back kitchen mangling - I did not hear her come down - there were six or seven bundles on the drawers in my front kitchen, and my daughter was there - she spoke to me at the back kitchen door, and said,"Mrs. Pendrell, I should not have known you" - she then walked up stairs - I thought she looked rather bulky - I then missed two bundles, containing this property - both the prisoners came in, but I only knew Murray.

ELIZABETH COKELY
. I am Pendrell's daughter. Murray came to our house between seven and eight o'clock - we had a great many bundles there - I afterwards missed two of them - the other prisoner came with Murray, and stood against the drawers where the bundles were - they remained a few minutes, and then went away - I did not observe any things about them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you quite sure you saw the other young woman there? Q. Yes; I was in bed in the kitchen at the time - I was awake - I did not see Furmery do any thing - she was against the drawers' but when the door was open, I could not see the drawers - I did not speak to her.

WILLIAM PETHEBRIDGE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shawl, a table-cloth, a pinafore, and an apron, which I took in from Murray on the 12th of July, about eight o'clock in the morning - the other prisoner was with her, but I had no dealings with her.

RICHARD GLOVER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three child's bed-gowns and a petticoat, pawned by Murray, on the 12th of July - I did not notice any body with her.

ANDREW JOHNSON
(police-constable D 108). The prisoners were given into my custody - I found two duplicates - one on each of them - and two duplicates were given at the station - in going along, they both went over some gratings, and I looked round, and found this duplicate, at Furmery's heel - I cannot say which dropped it.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they not both on the grating at the same time? A. No; Murray was a little before - perhaps a yard - they had both been on it - I found the other duplicate down the grating.

JAMES CLAPSON
(police-constable D 153). I have two handkerchiefs, and two aprons - I took them off the prisoners.

ANN HUNT
. I am the wife of Thomas Hunt - Mrs. Pendrell mangles for me - these articles are mine; and this apron, which was found on Murray.

MARY CROFT
. I am the wife of Edward Croft - I employed Pendrell to mangle - these things are mine, and the apron which was found on Furmery - I lost twenty-six articles - here are only two aprons, and two handkerchiefs.

JOHN LACY
. I produce a certificate of the conviction of Murray, on the 20th of December, in the name of Mary Murray - I know she is the person (read).

Murray's Defence. I was coming from Chelsea, and met this young woman - she had been in the Park all night - she said she was hungry - I told her to come to my mother, and I would give her something - we came to a coffee-stall, and I gave her coffee - she then asked me if I could take her backwards - I took her to Mrs. Pendrell's - she stood near the drawers, but I did not know that she had stolen any thing - when we came out, I saw her running with these two bundles - I came up to her, and said it was a person I knew very well, and it was a pity she took them; but I pawned them, and one is as bad as the other.

WILLIAM WINCHAPLE
. I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Drury-lane - I knew Furmery from her childhood - she had a good character - I will take her into my service.

MURRAY -
GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

FURMERY -
GUILTY. Aged 16. - Recommended to mercy by the Jury, believing her to have been the dupe of Murray . -
Confined Six Days .

1405.
PATRICK McDONALD
and
JOHN WALKER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August
, 70lbs. of lead, value 10s., the goods of
Samuel Hemmings
, their master ; and
JOHN SLIGHT
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen , against the Statute, &c.

McDONALD
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 30.

WALKER
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined One Month .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM PRICE
(police-serjeant S 21). I live in Brook-street, New-road
- on the 18th of August, I was at home - about noon I looked out at the second floor window, and saw McDonald pass, with the pig of lead upon his shoulder - he was preceded by Walker, who was looking about, till they came to the corner of Henry-street - McDonald then walked into Slight's shop, followed by Walker - they walked into the back parlour; remained there some minutes; and then came out without the lead - the shop door was open - it is a marine store shop - they walked straight in - I followed them - I had no coat on - Walker had a smock-frock on, and the other was in his shirt sleeves - they came out, and went to a new beer shop - I sent for a man, and placed him at the door of the beer shop - I went and got my coat, and went into Slight's shop, and into the parlour, as McDonald had done - Slight and two women were there - I told him I had come for the lead which two men had left - he seemed very much confused, and said it was down in the cellar, and if I would go down with him, he would give it me - he went out of the room into the passage - I looked about the room, and saw this lead under the drawers - I said, "Here it is; this is what I want" - he said, "Yes, there it is," or "that is it; take it away, and make no more bother about it," or "say no more about it" - I took him and the lead - he said he had given half-a-crown and a shilling for it, which was all the money he had; but they had asked 6s. for it - there were no other articles in the back room but the furniture and their own clothes - there was no counter or scales - when I had taken Slight to the office, I went back to the shop, and found, in the cellar, a quantity of cast-iron pipe behind some lumber, some of which has the mark of the New London Company - they were laying pipes in the neighbourhood.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is the mark? A. This painted mark - I stated to the magistrate that Slight said, "Don't make a noise" - I will swear that occurred - the pipe was broken when I found it - it was in twelve pieces.

SAMUEL HEMMING
. I am contractor for laying these pipes for the New London Company. McDonald and Walker were in my service in August - this lead is my property - I cannot tell whether I have lost any pipe.
Cross-examined. Q. How do you know the lead? A. Here are the marks "B. and Co." - the mould originally belonged to Blundell and Co. - all my lead has this mark on it.

JOHN RUSSELL
. I sell lead to Mr. Hemming - I have no doubt I sold this - we make it from the dross of white lead and other things - when Blundell and Co. left business, we purchased their moulds - I would give 8s. for this piece, to sell again.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you not sell this lead to your various customers? A. We generally sell it wholesale - all the lead we cast in these moulds has this mark.

MARY WILKINSON
. I live at No. 2, Mary-street - some lead was left on my premises - on the 18th of August, McDonald came, and said he had come for a piece of lead, and he took it - this is the piece as far as I know - I was not present when it was left - there were five pieces brought - this was the last - my house is eleven or twelve doors from Brook-street.

Slight's Defence. I was working in my back kitchen - I heard a noise, and went up - I saw these pieces of lead, and McDonald was standing there, very drunk - he sat down in one of my chairs, and said, "I want 6s. for this" - I said,"I will not have it" - he said, "I must have money to get more beer" - I said he had had beer enough, and I took out half-a-crown and a shilling - I said, "This is all the money I have - if you will come to-morrow when you are sober, we will talk about it" - the officer then came in - I was very much agitated - I opened the door - I then returned again - I stooped and took up the lead - he never stooped himself - I went with him to the station-house - I said, "I have not bought it - I had not money to pay for it" - I had only been there five or six weeks.

(
Thomas Rogers
, cabinet-maker, Margaret-street;
William Morgan
, cabinet-maker, Union-street;
James Rashford
, Galway-street; Mr. Baker, a plasterer; and Mr. Cabon, a plasterer, Mary-street, gave Slight a good character.)

SLIGHT -
GUILTY. Aged 54. - Recommended to mercy by the Jury . -
Confined for Two Years .

1406.
JAMES MULLINGER
,
GEORGE FERGUSON
,
MARY ANN FINN
, and
CAROLINE BURNETT
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 hat, value 7s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 1 sovereign; 2 half-crowns; 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences ; the goods and monies of
Alexander Betson
.

ALEXANDER BETSON. On the 23rd of July, I went to the West-end. I then took an omnibus, and went to the Tower - I then met Burnett, who asked me to go with her - it was then between nine and ten o'clock - I went with her to her own lodging - she asked me to give her some gin - I gave her a shilling, and she sent Finn for some - she gave me some in a tea-cup - I then went to bed, and felt sick - I had then a sovereign, two half-crowns, one shilling, and two sixpences - I felt it all safe just before I met this girl - after I felt sick, I went to sleep, and between one and two o'clock in the morning, the two male prisoners came and roused me up, and told me that was their bed - I said a young woman brought me there, and said it was her room - they said she had often done that when they were at sea - I then got up, and looked for my trowsers, which I had put under my head - they were gone, and I told the men I had been robbed - Ferguson found my trowsers at the foot of the bed - he heaved them at me - I went to where the rest of my clothes were, and my hat, handkerchief, and waistcoat, were gone - Ferguson then gave me an old hat, and told me to take that, and be d-d, and to be thankful to get a hat of any sort - I told them I would call the first policeman I found - Ferguson then led me into the court - when he saw a policeman he ran away - the officer came to me - I told him I had been robbed of my money and these articles - I went with him to the room at No.9, where I had been - it was then empty - the officers told me to stop there, and they went to No. 2, and found the two men and Burnett in one bed, and the other girl asleep in a chair - they called me to know ifthese were the men - I knew them, and they took them - I found my black silk handkerchief in the bed.
Burnett. Q. Were you sober? A. Yes.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Where did you see Burnett? A. On Tower-hill - I went with her about five minutes' walk - I had nothing but a little beer all day - I counted my money just before I met her - I had only been five days up from Scotland - I missed my money when the two men aroused me, and my trowsers were not where I left them - Burnett might have left me before the men came - I went to bed about half-past ten o'clock.

PIERCE DRISCOLL
(police-constable H 24). The prosecutor met me at the lower end of Blue Anchor-yard - I went with him to No. 9, Rose-court
- there was no person there - I went to No. 2, and found all the prisoners - Ferguson was on the bed with his clothes on - I found one sovereign, two half-crowns, and one sixpence, under a water butt in the room, and 1s. 6d. on Ferguson, and 13 1/2d. - the prisoners all said they knew nothing about the money - I have not found the hat, nor the waistcoat - this is the old hat they gave the prosecutor.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There was nothing found that the prosecutor could identify? A. No. He told me he went home with Burnett - Finn says she is servant to Burnett - the prosecutor was sober - he told me he got sick after taking the gin.

ROBERT THORPE
. I saw the prosecutor, and a man leading him down stairs - the man ran away - I should not know him again - I went to No. 9, and then to No. 2 - I found this handkerchief with the pad in it, under the bed where the prisoners were.

Burnett's Defence. I went home with the prosecutor - he was drinking with several more - he was very much in liquor when I first met him, and more when I left him, about eleven o'clock - I had no room of my own - I went to this young man's room to stop the night, as the prosecutor wanted to go at four o'clock in the morning.

FERGUSON -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

BURNETT -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

MULLINGER -
NOT GUILTY .

FINN -
NOT GUILTY .

1407.
JANE LOCKYER
,
WILLIAM WEST
, and
JOHN JONES
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 watch, value 9s.; 1 seal, value 3s.; and 1 watch key, value 1d.; the goods of
John Ladd
, from his person .

JOHN BEE
. I am a watchman, of St. Andrew's, Holborn. On the 7th of August, at half-past four o'clock in the morning, I saw a cab coming up Fetter-lane, driving very furiously - West was driving it, and the other two prisoners were in it - he drove to Holborn, and put it on the stand; the three prisoners then got out, and went to the coffee-shop in Farringdon-street - in about a quarter of an hour, I met them coming up Holborn-hill - I went to meet them; instead of coming up to the cab, they turned into Bartlett's-buildings - I followed them, and sent another watchman round another way - I followed them to Bartlett's - passage - I there saw Lockyer take something from her breast, which I thought was a watch, and give it to Jones, who put it into his pocket - West was with them - they were all close together - I then laid hold of Jones, put my hands into his pocket, and took this watch out - Lockyer then took the seal and key out of her bosom, and was in the act of dropping them, when the officer took them - they were all taken to the watch-house - 5s. was found on Lockyer, and 3s. on West.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. All you saw was Lockyer handing it to Jones, and he put it in his pocket? A. Yes.

JOHN MARCHANT
. I was constable of the night. The prisoners were brought into the watch-house - 3s. were found on West, and 5s. on Lockyer - I asked if she had any thing to say - she said she would tell me the truth - that she was at Vauxhall, and a gentleman hired a cab, and the cabman asked the gentleman if he would suffer his sister to ride with him, and the gentleman said yes, if she was his sister, and he desired the cabman to drive to York-street, Westminster; but instead of that they drove to Strutton-ground, where they got out of the cab, and the gentleman, the cabman, and a policeman went to a public-house, and had something to drink - that they got into the cab again, and the cabman drove to Piccadilly - when they got to the Green-park, the cabman desired her to rob the gentleman, which she did, that the cabman then took him out, and set him against the wall, and they three had got into the cab and drove away - she said West was the cabman, but he denied all knowledge of it.
Cross-examined. Q. Was she sober? A. Yes.
JURY. Q. Did she say the gentleman was drunk? A. She said he was asleep, and that Jones stood by while he was robbed.

JOHN LADD. I live in Little James-street. I was at Vauxhall that night - I hired a cab - West was the driver - I told him to drive to York-street, Westminster - he said the fare would be 2s., and asked if I would allow Lockyer, who was his sister, to ride home - I said if she was his sister she might, and she got in - I had a watch and seal and key when I got in; and after I left the cab and came to my senses I missed them - they drove me to Strutton-ground, and I had something to drink there, and whether there was any thing put in to it to make me stupid I do not know - this is my watch and seal - I am positive to West - I cannot swear to the girl.

Cross-examined. Q. How many public-houses had you been into? A. One before I got into the cab - I was there drinking brandy and water when the driver was sent for - we had two glasses of brandy and water between the driver and me and the waterman - I will not swear who proposed to go into the next public-house - I never was in the house before - I might have selected the house - I cannot say what I drank there - I cannot tell what I paid - I do not know exactly what money I had - I paid a shilling for a glass - I do not know whether there was more than one glass - the landlady brought it to me - I handed it to the prisoners to drink, and I was standing facing them - I was so stupid after drinking the first brandy and water, I cannot tell what I paid - I do not recollect getting into the cab again - I was going to York-street - I did wrong to get out of the cab and go into the public-house - I took no liberties with Lockyer.

CHARLES SIMONS. I am a watchman. I saw the cabcome out of Fetter-lane that morning - West was driving, and Jones and Lockyer were inside - they then went down Bartlett's-buildings - I heard some altercation - Jones struck West, who was very drunk - he fell off the cab two or three times - I parted them.

Cross-examined. Q. You say West fell several times? A. He must have done so, for he was all over mud - he was not quite sober when he went before the magistrate - when they went up Barlett's-buildings I thought the cabman had been robbed, as his breeches were loose - he was more likely to be robbed than to rob any one.

Jones's Defence. On the night in question I had been drinking with an old schoolfellow at the Admiral Keppel - West and the girl came there, and asked me to go and have a ride - I went to the coffee-shop, and we were quarrelling about it, when the watch was handed to West.

Lockyer's Defence. I was at the gardens, and the cabman brought me some drink - he brought the gentleman, who he said was his brother - I got into the cabman's place, and the cabman sat in my lap - we went on - the gentleman called a policeman, and said, "I will give you something to tell us where there is a public-house" - they then went to the public-house, with a female who was with me, leaving me outside - they sent me some rum-and-water out; and then they got into the cab, and we went to Piccadilly.
JOHN LADD re-examined. Q. Are you able to say you had your watch when you were at Strutton-ground? A. I had it when I got into the cab, and that was the first time I got out.

LOCKYER -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

WELLS -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

1408.
JOHN HANCOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 1 counterpane, value 4s.; 2 blankets, value 6s.; and 1 gown, value 1s. ; the goods of
Thomas Carter
.

THOMAS CARTER. I am coachman to a lady, in Old Burleigh-street. I occupy a room over a stable in Brooke's-mews
- I went out of town on the 23rd of August, and returned on the 27th - I then missed these articles - they were all there when I left - I had known the prisoner eighteen months.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Had he lodged with you? A. No; I gave him leave to sleep in the spare stall in the stable - I did not tell him he should not sleep there any more - I did not put his things away from the premises, but they were not in any room - the place where his things were, was open to half a dozen people - they were in an open space belonging to all persons - it was not locked up.

GEORGE ORPWOOD
. I am a coachman, and live in this mews - on the 23rd of August, about twelve o'clock at night, I was awoke - I heard somebody lift the latch - I heard it a second time - I got up and heard the prisoner's voice, asking if any body was at home - he then went towards Carter's room, and unlocked the door or something like it- he remained there some time - he then came out, and returned a second time to Carter's room - he remained there some time with a woman, and then went down - I looked and saw the woman go away first, and he after her - I got up at half-past five o'clock - I saw him coming up the mews, and he opened his trunk, and put something in.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know that he had been in the habit of being there? A. Yes; in the stable - he had nothing when he went out the second time.

JAMES NEWMAN
(police-constable C 109). I was on duty in South Moulton-street - I met the prisoner, and after he had passed me, I picked up a duplicate - I had not seen it there before - I went to the place it referred to, and found these articles.

Cross-examined. Q. How long was it since you had been at that place? A. About ten minutes - there were not many persons then passing - it was half-past five o'clock- it had not been there all night, for it was quite light, and I must have seen it.

GEORGE FARMER
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in these two blankets and counterpane of a man, but I cannot say who.

THOMAS JOSEPH WEST
(police-serjeant C 15). I took the prisoner - in going down the street I saw his hand was in his pocket - I said, "Keep your hand out of your pocket," and within a few yards the officer found the duplicate - this was a week after the robbery.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Confined for Six Months .

1409.
TIMOTHY KAYLOR
and
BENJAMIN BROMMAGE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Saint John Mason
, from his person .
2nd COUNT. For stealing from a person unknown.

GEORGE ANTHONY
. I live in Park-street, Camden-town. On the 24th of July, a few minutes past ten o'clock at night, I was at the top of Tottenham-court-road
- I saw the two prisoners and another attempting to pick pockets - I then saw Kaylor go and pick Mr. Mason's pocket of his handkerchief - I had watched them for half an hour - I called the policeman, and went and told the gentleman he had been robbed - I then crossed and took the prisoners - this handkerchief was found on Kaylor.

JOHN WILLIAMS
(police-constable E 99). I had been watching the prisoners for some time - Anthony spoke to me - I took Kaylor, and found this handkerchief in his right hand trowsers pocket.

(
Henry Tapp
, No. 2, Cromer-place; and
Celia Barton
, of No. 9, Spa-place, gave Brommage a good character.)

KAYLOR -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

BROMMAGE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1410.
ELIZABETH HARWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 3 half-crowns; 7 shillings; and 4 sixpences; the monies of
John Stafford
, from his person .

JOHN STAFFORD. On Saturday might, the 3rd of August, I met the prisoner, whom I had known before - we had a few words, and I went with her to a house - I had no money, and I sent the landlord of the house to pawn my watch - I got 20s. on it - we then had a pot of porter, a pot of half-and-half, and half a pint of gin - I had 16s. 6d. given to me, which I laid on the ledge of the window - I then went tobed, and I was found in bed - whether they had put any thing in the liquor I do not know, but I was in such a state as man never was in this world - I was so ill I could not go to work till the next Monday - when I awoke, the prisoner and all my money was gone.

WILLIAM SHEEN
. My mother is landlady of the house - the prosecutor came there with the prisoner - he sent me to pawn his watch - I fetched a pot of porter, and a half-pint of gin - I gave him the change - he drank but trifling, and then went up stairs with the prisoner - they had one pot of half-and-half up stairs by themselves - they went up about eleven o'clock, and in about fifteen minutes after the prisoner came down with a pot in her hand - she went to the water butt in the yard, rinsed the pot, and then drank herself - she then went up stairs, and tied her bonnet and shawl to her legs with a string - she went out - I fetched her back - I got an officer, who found this money in her shoe - the prosecutor was in such a state from the noxious drug that he had taken, that he could not be awoke till the next morning.

DENNIS REGAN
(police-constable H 22). I was called, and found 13s. 6d. in the prisoner's shoe, and 6s. in her hand - she owned that all the money belonged to the prosecutor but 5s. 6d.

Prisoner's Defence. This man said he was ill - he asked if I knew where he could get a lodging - I told him, and he said he should be glad if I would show him, and I did so - he said he had only one sixpence which he dropped on the pavement - when we got to Sheen's his watch was pawned, and half a pint of gin was brought in, and a pot of beer - they drank the gin, and we had the beer between us - the prosecutor then laid the money on the ledge, and it fell down, and he asked me to pick it up, and pay the reckoning - I said it was paid, and he laid down on his back - I went and told Mrs. Sheen the man was asleep, and I had his money - she said, "You can leave the house, but do not take the money" - I said, "No; I will not leave it, but in his presence" - she then wanted to take the money by force - I said, she should not - I went to put it in my shoe, but I could not get it all in - he then sent for the officer.

GUILTY - Aged 36.
Transported for Seven Years .

1411.
GEORGE KNIGHT
was indicted for
embezzlement .

ESTHER BELLAMY
. I am a widow . I keep a broker's shop , in Old-street
- I employed the prisoner, and gave him 1s. a day - on the 19th of July I told him to put up the shutters between eight and nine o'clock - I then said, "Take this butler's tray to Mrs. Burn's: you are to receive 4s. for it"- he did not return.

ANN BURN
. I was on a visit in Myddleton-square - I ordered the tray, and desired one of the servants to take it in - when it came I paid her for it, and she brought it to me - I believe she is now in the fever hospital.

PAUL PLANT
. I took the prisoner, and charged him with absconding from Mrs. Bellamy with 4s. for the butler's tray - he ran away - I took him again, and he said he did not care a d-n if he got lagged for it.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1412.
JOHN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 spoon, value 2s.; the goods of
Sydney Adcock
, his master .

SYDNEY ADCOCK. I am a jeweller , and live in Dean-street, Soho
- the prisoner was in my employ - I accused him of having taken some articles which I missed, and said if he would give me the duplicate I would forgive him - that was about half-past one o'clock in the afternoon - I called on Mr. Mills, in Oxford-street - he told me something, and I gave the prisoner into custody - he was taken to the station-house; and while being searched, this duplicate of a spoon was found on him - this is my spoon.
Prisoner. By what mark do you know it? Witness. I have the fellow in my pocket.

JAMES HOWELL
. I am a pawnbroker - this spoon was pawned by the prisoner, to the best of my belief - this is the duplicate I gave for it.
Prisoner. You told the magistrate you could not speak to the person Witness. I said to the best of my belief you was the person.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor can only swear to the spoon by having another like it; but are these the only two spoons that are alike? and supposing there are initials, there may be many others like them - when a new pattern is introduced, it is carried round and urged upon the trade; and when the shopmen sell them, they may fall into the hands of persons whose initials are the same - one might sell some to Michael Watts, he would take them to an engraver to put M. W. on them - another sells some to Mary Wilson, who has her initials put on them, and will it be possible to tell which were done for Watts, and which for Wilson? - and if there were even a crest on them, it is not possible to distinguish them - on the death of parents the plate is divided, the brother retains his, the sister takes hers to a refiner, who allows her 4s. 6d. an ounce for them, and she buys some of a modern pattern - you might purchase some of them of the refiner, and be under the necessity of pawning them - if you went to the brother's house, and the duplicate was found on you, how would it be possible to prove whether it was one sold by the sister, or one retained by the brother? - how then can the prosecutor swear to this spoon? - he has no proof that it was pawned by me, and the pawnbroker is unable to identify me - there is therefore no proof that I pawned or stole it - and this might be one of mine, as I purchased several spoons some time ago.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1413.
THOMAS HUGHES
, was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 921 pieces of ivory, value 29l.; 1 thermometer, value 6s.; 1 bottle of Eau de Cologne, value 2s.; 2 knife sharpeners, value 6s.; 12 cotton-reels, value 3s.; 1 china ornament, value 1s. 6d.; 12 pincushions, value 5s.; the goods of
Thomas Staight
, his master .
MR. BASSETT conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS STAIGHT. I live in Bartlett's-buildings
, and am an ivory-turner - the prisoner was in my employ upwards of three years - in consequence of information, I went to the office, and Lloyd produced one hundred and twenty ivory miniature leaves, which I was able to identify - theseare them - they are worth about 5l. - we then went and searched his lodgings, and found eight hundred pieces all together.

Cross-examined by MR. STAMMERS. Q. By what means do you know them? A. They are of a particularly fine quality - some of them have passed through my hands - these are very scarce - there is a particular grain in them - these are of nearly the same quality - I cut them myself - here is one with a particular mark, which I can swear to - here is another piece I can swear to - this little ornament I can swear to, and this thermometer; we had an accident and broke it - the prisoner never bought ivory leaves of me.

GEORGE KERSHAW
. I live at No. 17, Wilderness-row. On the 29th of July the prisoner came and brought me a sample of miniature ivory leaves - two or three of them - he said he had about one hundred, and asked me 30s. for them - I deal in such articles - I suppose they are worth 5l. or 6l. - I told him, when he produced the sample, I could not say any thing to the price unless I saw the whole - he returned in about an hour, and brought one hundred and twenty-nine - I told him he must go with me - I was going to take him to Mr.
George Staight
, the prosecutor's brother - I said I supposed they were stolen - when he got to Hatton-garden he refused to go any further - I took him by the collar, and took him to the office.
Cross-examined. Q. Will you swear to these other pieces? A. I think I can from my giving them to the officer - one piece has my writing on it.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I am an officer - the prisoner was given to me, on the 29th of July - I received this ivory from Mr. Kershaw - I went with the prosecutor to the prisoner's lodgings, and found these articles.(Property produced and sworn to.)(
Thomas Tyler
, a carpenter;
Edward Lane
, a painter, of Bedford-street, Commercial-road;
James Starrs
, a chairmaker;
James Gray
, of Rolls'-buildings, a glass-shade maker;
John Faulkner
, general-dealer; and
Robert Tabbut
, a carpenter, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1414.
GEORGE HAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , - of a yard of kerseymere, value 5s.; 3 pieces of lining, value 2s.; - a yard of silk, value 3s.; and 1 yard of cloth, value 15s. ; the goods of
John Woolf
.

The
Prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1415.
SARAH DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 shirt, value 8s. , the goods of
James William Saunders
.

ALICE SAUNDERS
. I am the wife of James William Saunders. The prisoner lodged at our house - on the 13th of August I had a shirt; I missed it, and went for the officer - he produced the shirt.

WILLIAM HORSFORD
(police-serjeant D 6). I went to the prosecutor's, and took the prisoner - I found this shirt, in a wet state, between the prisoner's bed and the sacking.
Prisoner. I was tipsy the night before.

GUILTY . Aged 58. -
Confined One Month .

1416.
WILLIAM CLEMENTS
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM MURRAY
. I am a stationer , and live in Oxford-street
. The prisoner lived with me - I told him to collect 2l. 13s. of Mr. Spicer - 14s. of Mr. Cable - and 3s. of Mr. Morgan - he never accounted to me for them - I asked him about the 3s., he said it had not been paid.

ALLEN LANG SPICER
. I deal with the prosecutor - I paid the prisoner 2l. 13s., on the 22nd of July , for his master.

HUGH CABLE
. I deal with Mr. Murray - I paid the prisoner 14s., on the 17th of July - it was his duty to give it to his master.

JOHN MORGAN
. I deal with the prosecutor - I paid the prisoner 3s. for his master, on the 29th of July .

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX
. I took the prisoner - he said he had spent the chief of the money in riding about in cabs.(Mr. Hall, of King-street, gave him a good character, and promised to employ him.)

GUILTY. Aged 15. - Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined One Week .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1417.
JOHN BAXTER
and
ROBERT STEWART
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 96 yards of Moreen, value 4l. 16s. , the goods of
Stephen Fawcett
.

EDWARD SMITH
. I am shopman to Mr. Stephen Fawcett. He keeps a carpet shop , on Islington-green
- on the 4th of July, the officer came in about six o'clock, and asked if we missed any thing - I looked, and missed four pieces of moreen from the side of the door - I went to the stationhouse, and identified them.

THOMAS HOBBS KING
(police-constable N 248). On the 4th of July I was sitting at my window on Islington-green - I saw the two prisoners and another cross the green, to Mr. Fawcett's shop - I knew them, and watched them - Stewart stood against the prosecutor's door, and Baxter walked backwards and forwards twice - he then took two pieces of moreen and gave them to Stewart - the other man then took two pieces and gave them to Stewart - I ran down and took Stewart with the four pieces on his shoulder - I asked him what he was going to do with them - he said, what was that to me - I said it was to me, he must go to the station-house - I seized Baxter - Stewart then threw down these pieces, and tried to get away - I got assistance, and he was secured.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. How far was Stewart from the shop door when the property was taken? A. The distance of the window; two or three yards.
EDWARD SMITH. This is my master's property - it has our mark on it.
Baxter's Defence. I was merely passing when this man was taken - I never saw him before.
Stewart's Defence. I was passing the green, and a man asked me to carry these.

BAXTER -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

STEWART -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1419.
ROBERT TEDMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 28lbs. of salt, value 7 1/2d., the goods of
Penry Lewis
, his master .

PENRY LEWIS. The prisoner was in my employ as carman - I employed him on the 21st of August to take two 500lbs. of salt to Highgate, to Mr. Humphreys and Mr. Sibley - Mr. Humphreys called on me the next day, and said he had not received his quantity.

JOSEPH HUMPHREYS
. I ordered a quarter of a ton of salt of the prosecutor - the prisoner brought it, and I missed this weight of salt from it - I was not at home when it was brought - it came loose, in a cart.

JOHN BULLEN
. I keep a general shop, at Highgate - I bought a bit of salt of the prisoner, on the day stated, it was about twenty-eight pounds - he merely called to me in the street and said, "Will you buy a bit of salt? itis the last I have got left" - I gave him 6d. for it - I buy every thing, and sell every thing - there was only that bit of salt in the cart - I did not know the prisoner before - I do not know how I came to buy it.

HENRY BRINDLEY
(police-constable N 223). I took the prisoner into custody.

SAMUEL LEWIS
. I am the prosecutor's nephew - I gave the prisoner two five hundred weights of salt to take to the two persons - we sell it at 59s. per ton - I should think 6d. for twenty-eight pounds was very cheap - it was put into the cart in large squares - a little might get off.

GUILTY. Aged 23. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

1421.
THOMAS CRAWTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 6 yards of kerseymere, value 2l.; 3 pair of trowsers, value 2l.; 1 hat, value 7s.; and 6 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; the goods of
Edmund Gooch
, his master .

EDMUND GOOCH. I am a tailor , and live at Poplar
- the prisoner was two months in my employ - I missed some kerseymere about the middle of July - I found it afterwards in Stepney-fields; but I believe the person is not here - on the 28th of July, about four or five o'clock, I called the officer, and asked the prisoner to go with him to his lodging, which he said he had lately taken - I asked him if he would show the piece of cloth which he said his friend had bought him.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you tell him you would not prosecute him? A. No - I went to where he was at work, and asked him to go to his lodging.

GEORGE BANNISTER
(police-constable K 234). I went to the place, and took the prisoner - the prosecutor said,"I have missed a piece of cloth, and can have no suspicion of any one but you" - he got off his board, threw his lapcloth off his knees, and said he knew nothing about his master's cloth - he said he lodged where he did, at No. 6, Edward-street - I left him there - I went to the office, took the order-book in my pocket, and returned - I then went with the prosecutor to a house in Wellington-street, where we found the cloth.

Cross-examined. Q. When you were sent for, did you know where to go to find this property? A. No: I left the prisoner while I went to the watch-house, and when I came back, I saw an alteration in his countenance - I said to him, "It appears to me you are guilty, and that the cloth you said your parents had bought you, is your master's, and if it is, you had better give it up" - he then said,"It is not at the lodging where I told you - I do not live there now" - he then took us to the place where the cloth was.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. My master and the officer promised if I would tell where it was, I should not be punished.(
William Hicks
, tailor, Albion-street, Commercial-road; and
James Morrison
, of Back-lane, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1422.
HENRY STONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 truck, value 5l.; and 1 dog harness, value 1s. 6d. ; the goods of
Joseph Robins, the elder
.

JOSEPH ROBINS
, Jun. I am the son of Joseph Robins, of Green-street, Stepney
, a carpenter . On the 7th of August, we had a truck at our shop, and the prisoner came to me, and said, "Joseph, I want your truck, if you can lend it me" - I said he could not have it for less than 3d. an hour - he wanted it for 2d. - I fetched it him - he said he should not want it more than two or three hours - he was to have brought it back, but did not - it has not been found - it was worth 5l. - I did not see him again till he was in custody - the harness was with it.
Prisoner. Q. What time was it in the morning? A. You came about half-past seven o'clock, but half an hour was allowed for the time I was talking with you, I know you.

GUILTY .* Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1423.
MARY ANN SHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 blanket, value 3s.; and 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d. ; the goods of
Edward Murrells
.

EDWARD MURRELLS. I live in Baltic-street, Old-street
. On the 27th of July, the prisoner hired my two pair back room - she stopped eight days - she then went away, and returned again, and stopped eleven days - then came back again quite tipsy, and gave me warning - my wife went up and missed the things - these are them.

ANN MURRELLS
. I went up, and missed this property.

CHARLES WORLEY
. I am a pawnbroker - I produce the sheet and blanket pawned with me on the 28th of July.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress.
GUILTY. Aged 31. - Recommended to mercy .
Confined Fourteen Days .

1424.
GEORGE SMITH
and
GEORGE BREWER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 necklace, value 6s.; the goods of
Henry John Northfield
, from the person of
Susannah Mary Northfield
.

WILLIAM BRITTLE
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Northfield, in Kingsland-road. On the 1st of August, my master's - little girl was playing at the door - I saw the two prisoners Smith undid her necklace - I went to them - he then dropped it - Brewer picked it up, and put it on the child's hand.
NOT GUILTY .

1425.
GEORGE SMITH
and
GEORGE BREWER
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 shovel, value 2s. ; the goods of
Charles Campbell
.

WILLIAM BRITTLE
. After these boys had taken the beads, I saw them cross the road to Mr. Campbell's oil shop - Brewer took the shovel from the private door - he gave it to Smith, and they walked away - I did not see them again till the next morning, when they went past - I told my master, and he gave them into custody.

CHARLES CAMPBELL
. I lost a shovel on the 1st of August - it has not been found - the prisoners were taken the next morning.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

BREWER -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1426.
MARY SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 sovereign, and 1 watch, value 2l.; the goods and monies of
Richard Doggett
, from his person .

RICHARD DOGGETT. I lodge in James-street, Oxford-street
. On the night of the 24th of August, I met the prisoner - she went with me to my lodging - we laid on the bed, and
William Lawes
, who is apprentice there, was in bed at the time - I undressed myself, and the prisoner was partly undressed - I then had a sovereign and a watch - I went to wind my watch up - I felt very sick - I put my watch into my pocket again - I then felt my sovereign there - the prisoner staid about twenty minutes - I then went to bed, and when I awoke in the morning, I missed my sovereign and watch - I went to Quebec-street, and found the prisoner - I gave her in charge.

WILLIAM LAWES. I was in bed, and I got up and put on the prisoner's stockings - she was tipsy, and she let a sovereign fall - I asked her if it was hers - she said, "Yes," and I gave it her - I could not make the prosecutor understand any thing - when the prisoner was at the foot of the bed, she said, "I have got the young man's watch"- I cannot tell whether he gave her the sovereign.

WILLIAM JOHNSON
(police-constable D 62). I took the prisoner - she stated where she lived - I went there, but could not find the watch - the prisoner said she gave it to the landlord to keep - the landlord said he knew nothing of it, but he came to the office and brought his daughter, who gave the watch to the prosecutor.

Prisoner's Defence. I do not know whether he gave me any thing - I was very much in liquor - I do not know what I did - I know one undressed me, and the other dressed me, and put me on the man's stockings.

MARGARET GREGORY
. The prisoner came to my house, and pulled out the watch - she said the man took her, and made her drunk, and she did not know what she did.
NOT GUILTY .

1427.
WILLIAM MURRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 coat, value 3l.; and 1 pair of trowsers, value 5s.; the goods of
William Hurford
, his master .

WILLIAM HURFORD. I am a tailor , and live in Bloomsbury
- the prisoner worked for me - I missed a coat and trowsers on the 12th of August.

WILLIAM COOMBES WATTS
(police-constable S 170). I found this coat and trowsers on the prisoner, on the 12th of August, about five o'clock in the morning - I stopped him on suspicion - he said he was going to Norwich to get work, and he had bought the trowsers in Somers-town - I said I would go there, but in going he said it was no use keeping me in suspense, he would tell the truth - they were his master's.
Prisoner. I was not in the habit of receiving my money every Saturday night, which forced me to do as I did.
GUILTY. Aged 22. - Recommended to mercy .
Confined Six Months .

1428.
FREDERICK MICHAEL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 hat, value 7s. , the goods of
Simon Simmons
.

SIMON SIMMONS. I deal in clothes , and live in Chapel-street, Edgware-road
. On the 18th of August, I saw the prisoner walking about the whole morning, with a newspaper in his hand, and no hat on - about two in the day, when the shop was full, he came in - he pulled out a card, and said, "I am a merchant, and to-morrow morning I shall have a cargo of goods, come over, that will stock all Marylebone" - I said, "Do not bother me; what do you want?" - he said, "A white hat" - I showed him one - he said, "This will do; I will go and look in the glass" - I thought he was going into my room, but he ran off in a moment - my neighbour followed and took him.

EDWARD ROBINS
. I keep a public-house, next door to the prosecutor. The prisoner came to my house the day before; he said he wanted lodging for a week, and his brother was coming from Paris with a cargo of goods - he said he had a large mansion in Paris - I showed him my bed room - he was satisfied with it - he had his breakfast and the newspaper - he took dinner, tea, supper, and bed - the next morning, he called for breakfast and the newspaper - at eleven o'clock, he called for a pint of ale - I took it to him, with the bill - he then walked out with his hands behind him, and came in with this hat - he said he had bought a very nice white hat, and he thought he looked better in a white hat than a black one - I thought he was going up stairs, but instead of that he bolted out at my back door - I followed in him about an hour and a half, and then came up to him, and said, "Do you mean to come back and settle this bill?" - he said he would come back and settle itdouble and treble - he went to eight or nine different houses, and wanted to borrow the money - he then said he would leave his coat with me for it.
(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had bought the hat for 7s. 6d., and went to his bed-room for his purse, which was missing, and he could not pay for it.)

GUILTY. Aged 23. - Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor . -
Confined Nine Months .

1429.
JOHN LOVESAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 2 shifts, value 2s.; 2 night-gowns, value 2s.; 4 aprons, value 4s.; the goods of
Lucy Ring
; and 1 towel, value 1s. ; the goods of
Thomas Bacon
.

LUCY RING. I am cook to Thomas Bacon, of Kilburn
- all these articles are mine, except a towel and an old bag, which belong to my mistress - I hung these things in the garden to dry, on the 5th of July - I was taken ill, and went to bed - I believe they were out all night.
Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. At what time did you see them? A. I cannot say what hour, but it was early in the day.

GEORGE HAWKINS
(police-constable S 43). I was on duty at a little after four o'clock the next morning, and took the prisoner with these things in a bag.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you see him? A. In the fields, coming from the back of Mr. Bacon's premises- I apprehended him, after a chase and a great deal of resistance - I searched him at the station-house, and found on him a knife and a counterfeit shilling - he made great resistance - I was an hour before I could get him out of the field - he got me down, and I was forced to draw my staff - I struck him twice.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the things.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Confined Six Days .

1430.
ELIZA HOLLIER
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHARLOTTE WILSON
. I keep a straw bonnet shop in Yardley-street
, the prisoner was not servant to me - she only came to learn the business.
NOT GUILTY .

1431.
WILLIAM HINKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns; and 4 Bank-notes, of 5l. each; the goods and monies of
William Harvey
, from his person .

WILLIAM HARVEY. I am a sailor . I was discharged at Chatham, and received 31l. 18s. - I had six £5 notes - I came to town, and arrived at three the next morning - I had my notes and my discharge in my pocketbook, which was between my shirt and my flannel - I went to a shipmate's wife, and gave her my money and clothes to take care of - I went to find my friends, who lived at Limehouse - I went back, and got my money and clothes - I went out, met some shipmates, and had a parting glass - I got very tipsy.

ELLEN McCARTHY
. I live in East Smithfield
. The prosecutor and the prisoner came to my house on the night of the 24th of July - the prosecutor was very tipsy, and the prisoner a little so - they came arm in arm - the prisoner asked for a bed, and said he would pay me for it - he said the prosecutor was a shipmate of his - the prisoner paid me 4s. - I showed them into the bed-room, and locked the door - I did not see that the prisoner had any thing in his hand then - he rang me up again, and wanted me to get some more liquor - I then saw that he had a pocket-book in his hand - he put it into his trowsers' pocket, and I sent for the policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Do you keep this house? A. No, I have only one room - I was once unfortunate; but I now work for my living - I never let a bed before that time - there was another girl in the house, whom I sent for the officer, but she does not live there - she is not an unfortunate girl - I let them have the bed, because they said they wanted one, and I thought I might as well have the money as any one else - I did not know the prosecutor had this money.

ROBERT THORP
(police-constable H 44). I was called, and searched the prisoner - in his left hand jacket pocket I found this pocket-book, containing 4 £5 notes, and the discharge from the ship - I took him to the watch-house, and found 3s. on him - he said he had no more money; but the next morning, I found two sovereigns in a rule-pocket - when I found the pocket-book on him, I asked if he was a shipmate of the prosecutor - he said he was; that he came in the same ship, and he was to receive 80l. the next day; and he had taken this book from the prosecutor to take care of it.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you happen to know that the prisoner has been on board a ship as a carpenter's mate? A. There was a character found on him from the Rainbow man-of-war.
WILLIAM HARVEY re-examined. Q. What vessel was yours? A. The Asia; I never saw the prisoner before.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not common amongst seamen to call one another shipmates? A. Yes.

GUILTY. Aged 36. - Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Nine Months .

1432.
JAMES GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 6 frocks, value 6s.; 1 gown, value 1s. 6d.; 1 apron, value 4d.; 1 pinafore, value 4d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; and 1 tippet, value 3d. ; the goods of
Robert Pepperell
.

MARY CONNER
. I am servant at the Ship and Whale, at Wapping-wall. The prisoner came the reon the 2nd of August, about seven o'clock in the morning, and left a bundle - my curiosity led me to look into it - I found in it these articles, which were all wet - he came back, and asked me for it - I refused to let him have it - he got an officer, who came and demanded the bundle, and I gave it the officer.

HANNAH PEPPERELL
. I am the wife of Robert Pepperell - we live at Bridge-place
. I had these articles in a tub in my yard on the 1st of August - I missed them the next morning, about twenty minutes past eight o'clock - I live two miles from the public-house.

JOHN STILWELL
. I am an officer - the prisoner came to me, and said his bundle was at the public-house - I went, and the witness gave me these things.
Prisoner. He told her to mind and swear what he toldher, as she would be well paid, and I should be convicted. Witness. I deny it all together.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

1433.
JOHN DUNKIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 timepiece, value 50s. , the goods of
Richard Palmer Green
.

RICHARD PALMER GREEN. I live in Bath-street, City-road
, and am a watchmaker . I missed this timepiece on the 8th of August, at eleven o'clock - I had seen it half-an-hour before.

EVAN DAVIES
(police-constable G 192). I was on duty in Whitecross-street. I saw the prisoner with a bundle under his arm, going along Long's-buildings, between three and four o'clock - he saw me, and ran off - I pursued and took him with this timepiece.
Prisoner's Defence. I was selling some books and garters - a young man asked me to carry this timepiece to Whitecross-street, and said he would give me 3d. - he saw the policeman, and ran off.
- WOOD . I am a cutler, and live at No. 32, Bird-street. The prisoner has been in my employ, and I will employ him again.

GUILTY . Aged 14.
- Confined Six Days .

1434.
WILLIAM COOK
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHARLES HORNE
. I live in York-place, St. Luke's
, and am a shoe-maker . The prisoner was in my employ, and it was his duty to receive money for me when I sent him with goods - on the 18th of July , I sent him to Mr. Campion, in Bridgewater-square - he was to receive 11s. 8d. for me - he did not return to me.

JOHN CAMPION
. The prisoner received 11s. 8d. of me on the 18th of July, for his master.

(
JOSEPH MARTIN
, of Bowl-court, Playhouse-yard, gave the prisoner a good character, and promised to employ him.)

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

1435.
ELIZABETH JONES
and
SARAH SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 18 yards of printed cotton, value 9s. , the goods of
William Spooner
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1436.
CHARLES WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 basket, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Robert Houghton
.

SARAH HOUGHTON
. I am the wife of Robert Houghton - we keep a shop in St. Marylebone
. On the 23rd of August, I was coming home in the evening, and saw a man looking at the window, next door but one to our house - the prisoner came from our door with this basket in his hand, and an open pen knife - I caught him, and told him he should not move, but he got from me - I called, "Stop thief," and the officer took him - he was not tipsy - this basket is my husband's.

HENRY GARNETT
(police-constable D 148). I heard the alarm, and took the prisoner - the lady had the basket - the prisoner said, "I should not have cut it, but some one told me" - I did not perceive that he was tipsy.

Prisoner's Defence. Another persuaded me to do it.(
John Newcomb
gave the prisoner a good character, and promised to employ him.)

GUILTY. Aged 17. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Six Days .

1437.
CHARLES KNATCHBULL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of April , 5 spoons, value 2l.; 2 glass decanters, value 6s.; 2 sheets, value 10s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; and 1 table-cloth, value 5s. ; the goods of
Maria Warren
.

The
prosecutrix did not appear. - NOT GUILTY .

1438.
JOHN PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 2 gowns, value 10s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; and 1 shawl, value 5s. ; the goods of
Mary Ann Cox
.

MARY ANN COX. I live in Peel-street, Kensington Gravel-pits
. The prisoner lodged at my house - he left on the 5th of August, and did not pay his last week's rent - I then missed these articles from my drawers by his bedside.

WILLIAM GOLDER
. I am a pawnbroker. These articles were pawned on the 5th of August, in the name of John Parker - I cannot say whether the prisoner pawned them, but his face is familiar to me.

THOMAS JOSEPH AVIS
(police-constable 39). I took the prisoner, and he produced this duplicate of the property.
Prisoner's Defence. My brother-in-law said if I would give up the duplicate he would say no more about it - the officer said the same.

THOMAS JOSEPH AVIS
. I never mentioned such a word, nor heard it mentioned.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined Six Months .
OLD COURT. - Wednesday, September 10th.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1439.
JOHN CHRISTINE WALDEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 2 coats, value 4l. 16s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l.; and two waistcoats, value 30s.; the goods of
Joseph Nathan
, in the dwelling-house of
Charles Lewis Israel
.

JOSEPH NATHAN. I have an apartment in the house of Charles Lewis Israel, in Leman-street, Whitechapel
. The prisoner is a tailor , and lodged in the house about three weeks - on Thursday morning, between seven and eight o'clock, I went out as usual, and came home late in the evening - I found my box broken open, and the property in the indictment gone - it is not worth 5l. - the prisoner was gone also.

CHARLES LEWIS ISRAEL. About a week after the prisoner came out of Newgate, I took him into my employ, knowing his father to be an honest man - I left him at work about eight o'clock finishing a waistcoat, and about half-past nine o'clock he left off work - I found him coming down stairs with a light in his hand - he blew out the candle - I could not see whether he had any thing - he came to my mother, and said, "How do you think I look in thewaistcoat my master has given me?" - she said, "Very well" - he said he would go out and buy a pennyworth of apples - he went out and never returned - this property was missed.

GEORGE CRAWLEY
. I am an officer. The prisoner slept in a house in West Smithfield, and left this property there to pay for his lodging - I was called in to the place, and asked him whose the clothes were - he said, his own - I said, they were too large for him - he then said they were his father's - I took him to the station-house, and he was liberated by the inspector.

LAWRENCE FITZHENRY
. I live in the house. I was told to see who was coming down stairs about half-past nine o'clock, and met the prisoner on the kitchen stairs - he had just blow the light out.

RICHARD PRICE
. I am a policeman. I had information about the prisoner, and went to his father's house - he was not there - I went next night to his father's house, and found him asleep, and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 15. -
Of stealing to the value of 99s. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1440.
JAMES DISBREY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 gelding, value 8l. ; the goods of
Charles Flanders
.

CHARLES FLANDERS. I keep a beer shop at Melburn, in Cambridgeshire
, which is forty-two miles from town - I lost a gelding from my stables about eight o'clock on the night of the 20th of August - the prisoner was in my yard during that day - he worked in the neighbourhood as a labourer - I suspected him, and came to town - I went to a constable, and at last met him in Old-street - I said, "Jem, you are the man I want" - he said, "Oh pray, oh pray forgive me" - I said, "It is out of my power" - I asked him where my horse was - it was a considerable time before he would tell me - at last he told me it was at his father's - his father is a chaff-cutter - I found the horse in his stable with another horse - I knew it to be mine.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You went to his father's directly you came to town? A. No; not till I found him - I inquired for his father's residence - I have known the prisoner some years, and he knew me - he has never taken my horse before, to my knowledge - I lost it on Monday night, and found it on Tuesday evening - I traced him to town with it - I heard in the village that he had taken it- he did not tell me he intended to return it - I did not say, at the office, that I did not think he intended to steal it - I said I did not expect he would bring it back - I said I did not wish to hurt him - I do not recollect saying, that as I was in a passion, I gave him into custody - I will not swear it, but believe I did not say any such thing.

JOHN WILLIAM WINTH
. I am a constable of Shoreditch. The prosecutor applied to me, and said the prisoner had taken his horse out of his stable, and desired me to go and look for it - he stated it to me as a case of felony - I said, "Do you mean to say he stole the horse?" - he said,"Certainly, what else could I mean?" - we met the prisoner in the street - the prosecutor said, "There is the man"- he caught hold of him, and said, "Jem, I want my horse, where is my horse?" - he did not answer - I took him into a shop - the prosecutor again began swearing, and said,"Where is my horse?" - he asked him to forgive him several times - we found the horse at the prisoner's father's stable, with another horse.
Cross-examined. Q. He was walking near his father's house? A. Yes, within one hundred yards of it - he told the magistrate he had come to see his father and mother.
CHARLES FLANDERS re-examined. My stable-door was not locked - I went out in the afternoon, and came home at eleven o'clock at night - the horse was gone - there is a door to the yard.
NOT GUILTY .

1441.
ROBERT LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 reticule, value 9d.; 1 purse, value 1s.; 1 key, value 4d.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 6 shillings; and 3 pence; the goods and monies of
Robert Mackay
, from the person of
Amelia Mackay
, his wife .

AMELIA MACKAY. I am the wife of Robert Mackay, who is a nurseryman at Stoke Newington. On the 28th of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in a field leading to Hackney
, opposite Park-road
- I had a boa on my neck, and a reticule in my hand - I heard a person walking behind me on the path - he came very close - I stepped on the grass for him to pass me - he came on the grass likewise - I turned round, and he pulled my boa from my neck - I snatched it from him, and he, at the same moment, took my bag from my hand, and ran off with it - it contained a purse, a key, a handkerchief, and 6d. - I immediately called, "Stop thief," and ran after him, calling,"Stop that man, he has stolen my things" - I lost sight of him for a very short moment - he got out of the gate of the field, and was taken directly almost by a policeman - he had got over a hedge - my reticule was found in the way he had run, in the hedge he jumped over - I have not a doubt the prisoner is the man.

JOHN RYAN
(policeman). I saw the prisoner running away - I followed him - he got over a hedge - the prosecutrix was holding up her parasol to give an alarm - I took him into custody, and found the reticule in the hedge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY .* Aged 17. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1442.
FLORANCE McCARTHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 jacket, value 1l.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 3s. ; the goods of
Henry Sheepwash
.
NOT GUILTY. The prosecutor did not appear .

1443.
MARY MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 2 table cloths, value 20s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 4s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 3s.; and 1 waistcoat, value 2s. ; the goods of
William James Mackrell
.

MARY MACKRELL
. I am the wife of William James Mackrell - I take in mangling, and live in Apple-tree-yard, St. James's
. The prisoner helped me off and on for eighteen months - I missed the property stated in the indictment on the 27th of July - I have found part of it - I suspected her, and gave information to the police.

GEORGE STONE
. I am a policeman. I received the prisonerin charge at the station-house, and searched her - she gave me eleven duplicates out of her own - hand - I asked if they were all her own - she said they were - two of them relate to this property.

JAMES CLOTHIER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of breeches, a table-cloth, and waistcoat - I do not know who pawned them - I gave the person these duplicates for them.

DAVID PERRYMAN
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Old Compton-street. I have a table-cloth which was pawned - I do not know who by - the duplicate of that has not been found.(Property produced and sworn to.)
(The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutrix had given her the articles to pledge instead of her wages.)
MARY MACKAREL. All the things but the table-cloth belong to my husband - there is not a word of truth in her statement.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined Three Months .

1444.
JOHN BALCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 4 tubs, value 5s. 6d.; 1 pail, value 1s.; 1 spoke shave, value 1s. 6d.; 1 cask of paint, value 10s.; and 7 wooden bottles, value 10s. ; the goods of
Henry Jarman
.

MARY ANN JARMAN
. I am the wife of Henry Jarman, and live in Henry-street, Old-street. We have a shop in Featherstone-street
, where he carries on the business of a cooper - the prisoner had nothing to do with the business - nobody had any business in the shop but my husband and his servants - the shop was locked up by a witness - I was told something was wrong there on the 30th of June, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I went to the shop, and found it broken open - I found this property at the station-house - the prisoner had nothing to do with the shop - we only rent the shop - I believe the prisoner worked in a shop over ours.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You do not live at the shop? A. No; I was there in the morning, as it happened at night - I go frequently every day - there are several workshops under the same roof - my husband was unfortunate in business, and has taken the benefit of the Insolvent Act - he has been in prison eleven weeks, and will be out next Monday - he was in Whitecross-street at the time.

CHARITY WOOD
. I am the wife of
William Wood
, and have the care of these premises - we live in the lower part, and occupy the parlours. About eleven o'clock at night I was going out to shut up the kitchen door - the prosecutor's shop faces the passage - I saw a light in his shop, and two men in it - I called my husband - we went down the yard and called to them, and asked what they wanted there - they made no answer, but put out the light, and came out very gently - one crept over the dust-hole, and tried to get over the wall - I pulled him away by his coat - he had a hammer in his hand - I looked at him and said, "It is you,
William Knowles
" - he got out at the street door, and has not been on the premises since, although his wife lives there - I found the prisoner standing behind the door by the things - I had seen him in the shop - the door had been broken open, and he was standing by the side of a great many of the articles - I said, "You have broken the shop open, and gone into the shop" - he said he had not broken it open, for he found it open - we talked to him, and wanted him to go, but he was very abusive, and insulted me, and said he would not go off the premises that night - we screened him too much, for my husband moved the things into the shop again - after that he abused us and struck my husband, I went for a policeman, who came and took him - the prisoner does not live on the premises, but was employed by a man who has a shop there - the other man lived on the premises, and works for his brother down the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. He told you he found the door open? A. He did - he attempted to strike my husband afterwards, but did not strike him - that was about twenty minutes after I found the shop open - they do not work very late - they do not work by candle light, but he was on the premises, because he associated very much with Knowles - his master's shop was locked up long before that.

WILLIAM WOOD. I have heard my wife's evidence - it is correct - I found the prisoner standing behind the door, and saw him come out of the shop - he had no right there at all - the other man escaped, and has not been taken - I found a poker which the door had been broken with.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you find the property? A. Outside the shop - the poker was about two feet from the prisoner - he said he would stop there all night - I said he should not - I quarrelled with him, and sent for a policeman, because he was going to strike me.

MATTHEW PEAK
. I am a policeman. I was sent for, and took the prisoner into custody - Wood gave him in charge for stealing a quantity of things out of Jarman's shop - I saw the poker there - it tallied with the marks on the door - I took that out of Knowles's room by the fire-place.

JAMES JOHNSON
. I am a cooper, and work for Mr. Jarman. I locked the shop up on Saturday evening, between nine and ten o'clock, and left every thing safe - the small casks were standing on the shelf, the washing tub on the ground, and the pail hanging on a nail - the prisoner had no right there - I gave the key to Mrs. Jarman - I know this property.
Prisoner's Defence. I solemnly declare my innocence - it is not an unusual thing for me to be in the yard - I have worked till ten or eleven o'clock on the premises by candle light.

THOMAS MERRYMAN
. I am a furniture japanner, and live on the premises - the prisoner was in my employ - he has worked there as late as ten and eleven o'clock when there was occasion for it - I was in my own apartment on the night in question - Wood called me down - I saw him in the yard, and considered he was something the worse for liquor - he remained there after he was charged with this - he has been in my employ upwards of a year and a half - he was a very honest man.
