COURT. Q. What part do you occupy? A. The shop over the prosecutor's - I have nothing to do with the prosecutor's shop - the prisoner said he had found the door open.

(
Zaccheus Hamilton
, Bunhill-row;
John Archer
, Old Nichol-street, Bethnal-green;
Henry Powell
, wood-turner;and
William Walter
, carpenter, Bagnigge-wells; gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 29. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined Nine Months .

1445.
JAMES BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Edward Thompson
, from his person .

EDWARD THOMPSON. I am a clerk in a solicitor's office , in Essex-street. On the 15th August, I was in Southampton-street, Strand
, between three and four o'clock - I felt my handkerchief taken from my pocket - I turned round directly, saw it in the prisoner's hand, and secured him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to Hungerford-market - I was walking up the Strand, looking in at the picture-shops - the gentleman turned round and accused me of stealing his handkerchief, which I am innocent of.

GUILTY .* Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1445.
THOMAS GUNTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
Thomas Hurst
, his master .

THOMAS HURST. I am a silk manufacturer . The prisoner has been my apprentice three years and a half - on the 28th of August, I and my wife went to bed in the first floor front room - the prisoner slept in the attic - I had ten sovereign and a half - in my trowsers pocket, which I put by the side of the bed - in the morning I got up, and missed a sovereign and a half - I told the prisoner I suspected him- he denied all knowledge of it - I sent for a policeman - I said, "You will not tell me where my money is; I dare say, you will tell the policeman" - they then went into the yard - the policeman afterwards showed me a sovereign, a shilling, and two sixpences - I asked the prisoner how he got it - he said, "I got up at four o'clock in the morning, and took your money, and then went to bed again" - my bed-room door was shut, but not locked.

JOSEPH WORMALD
. I am a policeman. I took the prisoner - I went into the yard with him, down into the cellar - he went down on his knees, and began searching for the money - I helped him, and found this money concealed under the dirt in the cellar - he picked up a sovereign; I found the silver - he said he went down at four o'clock in the morning, opened his master's door, and took the money out of his purse, in his pocket, and then went to bed - he said his mother told him to take all the money, for she had no tea nor sugar.

GUILTY. Aged 19. - Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor . -
Confined Three Months .

1447.
ELIZABETH PERRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 7s.; 1 hat, value 5s.; 2 aprons, value 6d.; 2 pairs of half-boots, value 1s.; 1 box, value 2d.; 1 handkerchief, value 3d.; 6 shoes, value 6d.; 2 shillings; 3 sixpences; and 6 1/2d., in copper monies ; the goods and monies of
Charles Wilkinson
.

SARAH WILKINSON
. I am the wife of Charles Wilkinson; I sell things in the street. I have known the prisoner about a fortnight - I employed her to clean my room and wash my children - she did not live in the house - on Sunday afternoon, I was cleaning myself, and missed my husband's trowsers and hat; and in the morning, I missed his coat off my bed - she had left the place at a quarter past nine o'clock at night, and wished me good night - she said she would come soon in the morning - my pocket was taken from under my head while we were in bed, at one o'clock in the morning.

JOSEPH RENSHAW
. I live with Mrs. Wilkinson. I was taken ill at one o'clock in the morning, and came down stairs - I found the street door open, and about three yards from the door sat the prisoner, with the coat on her back, and the bonnet on her head - she had left the house - I said,"You have got Mr. Wilkinson's coat on" - she said Mr. Wilkinson had given her it to put on - I called the prosecutrix - the policeman came - there was no light in the room - the prosecutrix's husband is a milkman, and goes out at two o'clock in the morning - I found several of the prosecutor's things thrown upon the stairs, towards my room - the prosecutrix being called, missed the pocket from her bed.

JAMES CLAPSON
. I am a policeman. I was sent for, and found the prisoner in custody - I found the shoes tied up in an apron - she had taken them out of her pocket - I found 4s. 0 1/2d. on her person.

SARAH WILKINSON re-examined. I lost 2s. 2 1/2d. from my pocket, and my husband lost 1s. 9 1/2d. from his pocket - this is my husband's tobacco box - the coat and all the property are ours - my husband had nothing to put on when he got up.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1448.
WILLIAM THOMPSON
and
GEORGE STONE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 saw, value 4s. , the goods of
Richard Mason Wood
.

ALEXANDER WHITE
. I was in Chiswell-street
on the 27th of August, about half-past eight o'clock in the morning, and saw the prisoners in company together - I watched them, and saw them cross the street to Sowerby's, the pawnbrokers, and loiter about for some time - they then crossed over to Wood's shop - a saw laid in the passage - I saw stone go in, and when he came out he had the saw in his hand - Thompson was waiting outside for him - I directly went over to Mr. Wood, and saw Harrison, and told him - I pointed them out when they got to Bunhill-row - I had seen Stone hand the saw to Thompson - I called "Stop thief," we overtook them, and they were secured at the corner of Jewin-street.

ROBERT HARRISON
. I am errand boy to Mr. Wood - White gave me information - I went in pursuit - I overtook the prisoners, and they were secured - here is the saw.

EDWARD McDONAL
. I am a City policeman - I have had the saw ever since I took the prisoners into custody.
RICHARD MASON WOOD. I am a printer - this is my saw - it lay near the doorway.

Thompson's Defence. I was passing along the street, somebody going by, with a fustian coat on, dropped something - I picked it up - it was the saw - I did not run away with it till after I got some distance - when I heard a cry of"Stop him with the saw" - I then turned back, and gave the saw to the witness.

Ston's Defence. I know nothing of Thompson. I was looking about for a situation - I happened to ask him if he knew of one - he said he did not - I went on - he said,"Good bye" - and shortly after the witness cried "Stop thief" - I ran with the mob, and when they got down the street they gave me in charge.
(Mr. Jones, solicitor, of Brunswick-square, gave Thompson a good character.)

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

STONE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Six Weeks .

1449.
MARY BLEWIT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 shawl, value 10s. , the goods of
James Aldous
.

JOSEPH NOTLEY
. I am in the employ of James Aldous, who is a pawnbroker in Berwick-street
. On the 22nd of September the prisoner came to the shop - I knew her before, and watched her - I saw her go up to a shawl, and unpin it - she went to a partition in the shop, returned, and took another pin out - she returned a third time, and took the shawl down and retired again - and the fourth time, she went and took a pin out of another shawl - two gentlemen came in to purchase a gun, and then she went out - I pursued, and overtook her six yards off, and found the shawl on her.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you sure you saw all this? A. Yes; she has pawned at our house to the amount of 3l. or 4l., I should think.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found the shawl on the ground when I went in - I have been in the habit of going there for nine years - he has got a great deal of my property in his house.

GUILTY . Aged 53. -
Confined Three Months .

1450.
HENRY HART MORDECAI
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 30 shillings , the monies of
Thomas McGillivray
.

THOMAS McGILLIVRAY. I am a surgeon in the East India Company's service - the prisoner was in my employ for some time, to go out with a variety of curiosities which I brought from India from time to time, to dispose of them - I paid him for his trouble - I gave him a gun to dispose of - he returned and said he only got 4l. 10s. for it, and he had got 6l. for it - he was to sell it for me, and bring back whatever he got for it - I told him that I had discovered he had sold it in St. James's-street, instead of Piccadilly as he had told me, and for 6l. instead of 4l. 10s. - he said he sold it first for 4l. 10s. in Piccadilly, and went and purchased it again, and sold it for 6l. - the money was never in my possession.
NOT GUILTY .

1451.
DANIEL HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 2 pictures, value 40s. , the goods of
James Black
.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I am a constable. I was going down Rodney-street
, and saw the prisoner and another, about four o'clock in the afternoon, near the prosecutor's house - on my getting near them they moved - I went up Henry-street and watched them - they returned, and sat near the same spot again, and in about ten minutes the prisoner went up the prosecutor's gateway, he was in the fore-court a few minutes, and then returned to the other - there was some music playing in the street - they went to it - I saw the one not in custody, get in at the window - the prisoner stood close to the window, and lifted it up while the other got in, and delivered these two pictures out to the prisoner, who ran towards the road - the other man ran in a contrary direction - I ran and secured the prisoner with the property - I asked where he got it - he said he found it.
JAMES BLACK. These are my pictures, and were in my room.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming along the road - a lad asked me to carry the pictures to Charles-street.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Months .

1452.
MARGARET BENSON
and
ELLEN BENSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , at St. Mary-le-bone
, 1 topaz cross, value 30s.; 1 turquoise cross, value 1l.; 10 rings, value 10s.; 1 pair of brooches, value 5s.; 3 brooches, value 20s.; 1 buckle, value 10s.; 2 lockets, value 5s.; 3 pair of ear-rings, value 16s.; 3 gold drops, value 4s.; 1 watch key, value 3s.; 1 miniature, value 2s.; 7 pieces of lace, value 30s.; 1 ivory fan, value 6s.; 4 cups, value 4s.; 2 plates, value 2s.; 8 yards of flannel, value 4s.; 4 pieces of linen, value 8s.; 2 pieces of muslin, value 7s.; 4 plumes of feathers, value 10s.; and 12 remnants of linen, value 3s.; the goods of
William Archer
, in the dwelling-house of
John Wyatt
.

CAROLINE ARCHER
. I am the wife of William Archer. I lodge in the house of John Wyatt, in Edgware-road
, in the parish of St. Mary-le-bone. The prisoners used to clean my room, but they had no regular occupation - I admitted them to my room from kindness - I am not in any business - they were out of situations - while they were there, I missed all this property from the back room second floor - some was in boxes, some in drawers - on the 29th of June, during their absence, I discovered some boxes opened, and on their return, I named several articles that were taken, but I had not examined the boxes from the time I came there, which was the 29th of April - (Ellen helped me to move) - they were in my room during my absence - the property was found in their apartment - Ellen went to a situation, I understand, on the Tuesday preceding - they had left my place without notice - when I came home on Sunday, the 29th of June, Margaret was gone - I had been out to dinner, and left her there, and came back.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did not you desire Ellen to seek for another place? A. She was seeking for a situation all the time she was with me - I have a sister named Mrs. Hance, whom I lived with before I came to where I am now - she did not come backwards and forwards to my lodging, to my knowledge, nor any of her family - I left my sister because she left her house - I never charged my sister with any thing in particular - I may have missed thing during the time I was there - I do not think I charged her with robbing me - I swear to the best of my knowledge I did not - I lost things - I did not charge her with breaking open my boxes - Hance was not at my apartments, to my knowledge - the apartments were in the care of the prisoners.

Q. Did you not intrust the property to the prisoner, that Hance might not take it? A. I only desired her to stay there - if Mrs. Hance came to my house, it was against my wish - I never found her hid under the sofa - I never said so to any body.

RICHARD BRADSHAW
. I am a policeman. On Friday, the 4th of July, I went to Great Charlton-street, Somers'-town - I found the two prisoners lodging there - they came home about ten o'clock - Ellen opened the street door - I crossed the road, and said to Margaret, "I want you: where is Ellen?" - she turned round; I said, "Ellen, I want to speak to you also; it is very particular what I wish to tell you, will you walk a few yards with me? I want you about the Edgeware-road business" - they looked at each other, and said nothing - I said to Margaret, "You have no shawl on, would you wish to go home for one?" she said not - I said, I must take them to the station-house - I said,"Mrs. Wyatt says she saw you come out on Sunday night with a bundle each" - Ellen said, "It is false, we had no bundle, it was only this small basket, I had nothing else"- I said, "You went home in a cab" - they said, "Yes, we saw an empty cab in the New-road, and called it" - on getting to the station-house, I searched her basket, and found a piece of ribbon, two watch-hooks, and one custard cup - I found two keys, one of the street door, and one of their room - I went next morning to their room with the prosecutrix, and, on opening a box, I found all this property, which Mrs. Archer identifies - I found twenty-one duplicates in their boxes not relating to the property.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not Ellen say the box you found the property in, was intrusted to her by Mrs. Archer? A. No; she was not present - she said nothing of the sort at the office.

WILLIAM HORSFORD
. I am a policeman. I was with Bradshaw - I found fifteen duplicates, which relate to part of the property, tied together in a small box.

EDWARD JACKLEY
. I live at No. 9, Charlton-street. I let the room the officer searched to the prisoners.

HENRY BAYFIELD
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a necklace pawned on the 7th of June - I do not know who by - the duplicate I gave the person is among those produced.

JOHN ABBETHAITE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have five remnants of muslin - I do not know who pawned them - here is the duplicate I gave the person.

ROBERT JOHNSON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three remnants of muslin, a brooch, and two clasps - I do not know who pawned them - here are the duplicates I gave for them.
Cross-examined. Q. Is Mrs. Archer in the habit of pawning at your place? A. Not to my knowledge - I do not know Mrs. Hance.

ELIZABETH WYATT
. I am the landlady of the house Mrs. Archer lives in. On the 29th of June, I saw the two prisoners go out at the passage door - they had something in their arms, but what it was I do not know - they could go in, and out at any time.
Cross-examined. Q. Could they that afternoon have had that box with them? A. No; but they often went in and out.

THOMAS HOLLOWAY
. I saw two young women driven up to the prosecutrix's lodging in a cab - they got out with something in their hands - I cannot say what it was - I will not swear it was the prisoners.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Margaret Benson's Defence. Mrs. Archer left her house at six o'clock in the morning - her sister ran away in debt- after that the prosecutrix gave me the box to take care of- she said she had found her sister under the sofa - the necklace was given to me by Mrs. Hance last September.
Ellen Benson's Defence. She gave me some things to take to my sister to take care of, as she could not trust her sister.
MRS. ARCHER re-examined. I found my niece under the sofa once, but not my sister.

MARGARET BENSON -
GUILTY . Aged 25.
ELLEN BENSON - GUILTY. Aged 20.
Of Stealing to the value of 99s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .
There were two more indictments against the prisoners.

1453.
WILLIAM HALL
and
JOHN HALL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 necklace and clasp, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
William Wilmot
, from the person of
Henry Walter Wilmot
.

ANN WILMOT
. I am the wife of William Wilmot. My son Henry Walter Wilmot is fifteen months old - we live in Western-street - I sent my little boy out with his brother, who is nine years old - he had a coral necklace on, and a clasp - he returned a quarter of an hour afterwards without it.

JOHN BRETT
. I saw this boy and his brother out - I saw the two prisoners and another together - I watched them for five minutes all three together - I saw them follow the children to a bird shop - William Hall stooped down and unfastened the necklace - they all ran off - they were pretending to be looking into the bird shop - they were all three round the child - John Hall and the other one stood on each side of him - I cannot say who took it off - I ran home, and told my father of it - he ran out and asked the boy if he had lost any thing - he said, "No" - the prosecutrix came up in about five minutes - I am certain the prisoners are the boys.

CHARLES GRINHAM
. I am a policeman. I saw William Hall in company with one McDonnell, in Brill-row, about a quarter of an hour before, and had seen them all three in company with others - I apprehended the prisoners - I have not got the property.
John Hall's Defence. The policeman turned us out of the archway - several boys ran down the road where these children were, but I ran away - I know nothing about the necklace - I never saw it.

WILLIAM HALL -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

JOHN HALL -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined for Six Months .

1454.
JOHN HYLAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 veil, value 20s., the goods of
John Wyld
, his master .

JOHN WYLD. I am a haberdasher , and live in Rathbone-place
- the prisoner was my porter for about two months, and slept in my shop - I had some suspicion, and opened his trunk on Monday, the 1st of September, I found someduplicates there for a pair of half-boots, and a veil - I missed two veils.
Cross-examined by MR. STAMMERS. Q. Was it quite a new veil you missed? A. Yes - It cost me 24s. - I should sell it for 28s. - it had a mark on it, but not when it was found.

DAVID FARROW
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 4, Ryders-court. I have a veil pawned on the 16th of August, to the best of my recollection by the prisoner - the duplicate produced is what I gave for it.

Cross-examined. Q. Is that a new veil or has it been worn? A. I should take it to be a new one - I advanced 10s. on that and a pair of half-boots - it is worth about 20s., - to the best of my recollection it was the prisoner - I have not the slightest doubt about him.
Prisoner. Q. Did not your master say it was but an old one, and he could not advance more? A. Not to my recollection.
MR. WYLD. I have not a doubt of this being my veil- I never saw another of the same pattern - I took the prisoner out of charity, and was to give him 15l. a-year - he denied pawning it.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1455.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 2 shillings , the monies of
William Griggs
.

ELIZABETH GRIGGS
. I am the wife of William Griggs- we keep an oyster-shop in Whitechapel-road
- I saw the prisoner come to the shop on the 2nd of September, and had four oysters - they came to 2d. - he gave my daughter 1s. - she had not got change, and put 6d. on the top of the place where the till was, and went out for change - a man and his wife were talking to me about the house - I was showing them the outside of the house - I turned round, and saw the prisoner's hand in the till - I ran in, turned quick round, and said, "You good-for-nothing man, what do you do with your hand in my till?" - he said he had not done so - my daughter came in with the change - I said,"What is in the till?" - she said, "2s." - she looked in the till, and they were gone, but there was one bad one in the till - she said, "You have taken two good ones out, and put one bad one in" - another daughter fetched an officer, who took him into custody - he gave the two shillings out of his pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Did you say your daughter put any thing near the drawer on the till? A. No. There was a little chest of drawers, which we use as a till - my daughter had put out 6d. towards the change - the prisoner could not be putting his hand over to take the 6d. - I swear I saw his hand in the till - I did not like to give him in charge, as it was a disagreeable thing - I did not say I would have 2s. out of him - he snatched the bad shilling out of my daughter's hand, and gave the two shillings back - he had not left the shop before I sent for a policeman - he was gone out when the policeman came.

ELIZABETH GRIGGS
, Jun. The prisoner came for the oysters, and paid me 1s. - I put 6d. on the top of the till for him, and then went to get change - I had looked into the till to see if there was change, and there was not - there was 2s., and the 6d. laid on the top - they were both good shillings, I believe - when I returned, my mother told me what had occurred - I said, "You good-for-nothing man, you have taken two shillings out of the till, and put this bad one in" - he snatched the bad shilling out of my hand, and put 2s. into my hand.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you not insisted on his giving two shillings before he left the shop? A. I said, "Give me the 2s. you have take out of the till," and he gave it me directly - I might have taken a bad shilling without knowing it.

EMILY GRIGGS
. I fetched a policeman. The prisoner had given my sister the two shillings and gone away when the policeman got there.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go after the policeman? A. I found him two or three doors off - nobody sent me.

ISAAC JOHN ISAACS
. I am a policeman. I took him into custody.
NOT GUILTY .

1456.
FRANCIS HAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August
, 3 silver spoons, value 1l. 4s., the goods of
Robert Owen Aland
, his master ; and
GEORGE BLAKE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
There being no evidence against the prisoners, but a confession which was extorted, they were
ACQUITTED .

1457.
FRANCIS HAYES
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 16th August
, 2 tea-spoons , the goods of
Samuel Hart
; and
GEORGE BLAKE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
SAMUEL HART. I lodge in the house of Mr. Aland, the last prosecutor. I missed two tea-spoons - I was informed by Brillett where I could find them.

JOHN BRILLETT
. I found these tea-spoons pawned at Soames's, at Chelsea.

EDWIN SOAMES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two tea-spoons - I do not know who pawned them - it was a youth- the duplicate has not been found.
NOT GUILTY .

1458.
SAMUEL CARTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 sovereign , the monies of
Edward Richard Phillips
.

EDWARD RICHARD PHILLIPS. I live in Great Titchfield-street
. On the 2nd of September, the prisoner was pointed out to me, and I gave him into custody of the police.

ELIZABETH PHILLIPS
. I am the wife of the prosecutor. On the 2nd of September, I saw the prisoner selling rabbits - I took him to my door, and bought two of him for 1s. 2d. - I had no small change - he heard me send my servant for change of a sovereign - she came back, and said she could not get change - she went out again, and came in, and said the prisoner had run away with the sovereign.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ever deal with him before? A. Never - it was at half-past eleven o'clock - my servant came back the last time about twenty minutes to twelve - the prisoner had no donkey with him.

MARGRET HUMPHREYS
. I am servant to the prosecutrix - I remember the prisoner being at the door - mistresssent me for change - I went to several places, but could not get change - I came to the door, and told the prisoner I could not get change - he said if I would give him the sovereign, he would go to the public-house and get change - he went in at one door and out at the other, and I never saw him afterwards - I had given him a sovereign to get change - I am sure he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. Why did not you go into the public-house? A. I did, and he was gone - there are two doors to the house - I was not frightened - I never dealt with him before - it was about a quarter before twelve, on Tuesday, the 2nd of September - mistress bought two rabbits, and he left some behind him - I did not count them - we gave them to the policeman.

MR. PHILLIPS re-examined. When the prisoner was pointed out to me, he said, before I spoke to him, "I hope you do not think I am the man who stole the sovereign?"- we were talking about the thing at the time.

THOMAS GREEN
. On Tuesday, the 2nd of August, I was in Tottenham-court-road, and saw the prosecutor and prosecutrix talking to the prisoner, opposite a public-house - I heard the prosecutor saying, if a policeman came by he should give him into custody - he saw me, and gave the prisoner into my custody - he told me he was innocent; that all he had to sell that day were two bushels of onions, one bushel of which he sold to Mr. Shoolbred - I found 13s. 6d. on him - seven rabbits were brought to the station-house.
The Prisoner called the following Witnesses.

- CONNER . I am fifteen years old - about twelve o'clock, on the 2nd of September, I saw the prosecutrix with a basket in her hand - she asked the price of two rabbits - I went over and asked if she wanted any onions - she said, "Come a little higher up" - the prisoner is not the man she was bargaining with for the rabbits - I should know the man if I saw him.

JAMES MARSHALL
. I saw the prisoner on the 2nd of September, about twelve o'clock, selling apples and pickling onions, with his wife, at the corner of East-street, Paddington - they had a donkey and two hampers.
NOT GUILTY .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1459.
JOSEPH EDWARDS
was indicted for a
misdemeanour .

JOHN JAMIESON STEVENSON. I am clerk to William Thompson and Co.
On the 21st of July , the prisoner came to Mr. Thompson's wharf, in Upper Thames-street
, and brought this order for half a hundred weight of bar tin, for Gardner and Co. - he merely produced that paper, the tin was weighed and delivered to him - I never knew him in Gardner's employ - they are customers of ours - he took it away on his shoulders - I should not have parted with it unless I believed he came from Gardner and Co. - we debited them for it.

JOHN NICHOLLS
. I am one of the firm of
John Gardner
,
Robert Alexander
, and others. The prisoner had been in our employ, and left about six months - I do not know the handwriting on this order - the prisoner had no authority to obtain goods in our name - he never brought it to our house- he was in our house several years - I had very little to do with him, and do not exactly know when he left. (Order read).
"Send, for Gardner and Co., - a cwt. of bar tin.
21st of July, 1834."

Prisoner's Defence. I had the note sent to me for the tin - I never mentioned Mr. Gardner's name - I delivered the tin to the person who gave me the note - he said he had it from Gardner - his uncle was named Gardner, and kept the Globe, in Mile-end-raod - he lived at Twigfolly.

JOHN JAMIESON STEVENSON re-examined. We had no other Gardner a customer - I understood by the order I was to deliver this for Gardner and Co., of Cow-lane - I put no questions to him - I did not know he ever was in Gardner's service - on the 26th, he came again, and presented this order to me, and said, "I have got an order for you" - I said, "Very well;" and desired one of the men to weigh it - in the mean time, I sent for a constable - he returned in a quarter of an hour without one - we told him we must detain him while we sent to Gardner's - he then looked towards the door - seeing no chance of escape there, he plunged into the Thames, and attempted to destroy himself.
Prisoner. By some means I slipped into the water - I did not exactly know what I was about - that note was also delivered to me.
JOHN NICHOLLS re-examined. The prisoner was not employed by our house, on the 26th of July, to procure any quantity of bar tin - this note is not in the handwriting of any of our firm.

GUILTY .
Confined Three Months .

1460.
RICHARD HUNTER
was indicted for a
misdemeanour .

EDWARD GILBERT
. I am book-keeper at the King's Arms, Snow-hill
- on the 17th of July , the prisoner came with a parcel, directed to Mr. Johns, Portsmouth - the booking was two-pence, and he gave me a bad crown piece - I said it was bad - he said he did not know it - I looked at the parcel, and collared him - he said, "Why do you collar me?" - I said I thought it was a made up parcel, and asked where he got it - he said some man gave it him at the corner of Farringdon-street to bring to the office - the parcel was opened the next morning - it contained a wisp of straw - the officer was sent for, and took the prisoner with the crown-piece in his hand.

THOMAS JOSEPH AVIS
(City police-constable No. 39). I was sent for, and took the prisoner with the crown piece - I took him to the compter, and found two half-crowns and one shilling and two pence halfpenny on him - here is the parcel.
Prisoner. I gave the parcel and the crown to a young man behind the counter.
EDWARD GILBERT. There was a lad in the office who took it, and gave it to me the same moment - I have the control of the office, and should have lost the five shillings.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into a public-house, and a well-dressed young man asked me to take the parcel to the King's Arms - I took it - he walked with me to the corner of Farringdon-street, and said he would wait till I returned- I gave the crown piece which he gave me to a young man, who carried it to the book-keeper - he came, and took me by the collar - I asked him what for - he said, did I know what was in the parcel - I said I did not - the money found on me was what I worked for.
(The crown piece being broken, was composed of Britannia metal.)

GUILTY . - Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .
NEW COURT. Wednesday, September 10, 1834.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1461.
RICHARD HARTLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September
, 3 shillings; the monies of
George Walker
and another, his masters ; also, for
stealing, on the 28th of August
, 1 snuff-box, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 silver medal, value 5s. ; the goods of
George Walker, jun.
; to which indictments he
pleaded GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1462.
GEORGE STEWART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 pair of scissars, value 2s. ; the goods of
Richard Buckingham
; to which he pleaded GUILTY. Aged 61. -
Judgment Respited
.

1463.
ISAAC FERRY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 28th of July , 3 pairs of shoes, value 19s., the goods of
William Langley
, he well knowing the same to have been stolen .

CHARLES BRITTON
. I live in the New-road, St. George's
. I am foreman to my uncle, Mr. William Langley - he is a shoemaker - I missed three pair of Blucher shoes on the 28th of July, when the officer told me of it - I had seen them safe on the Saturday night before, at seven o'clock - I went with the officer to Hare-street, Brick-lane - I saw the prisoner standing at his door - Smith, who went with me in plain clothes, asked him whether he had any shoes to sell that would fit him - the prisoner pointed to some over the door, and said, "There are some" - the officer said,"They are not good enough, have you any thing better?"- he said, "No, I have nothing better" - Smith then asked whether he had bought any on Saturday night - he said, No, he did not - Smith then said he had information that there were some sold there which had been stolen - the prisoner said, "No, I never do business in that way - I never buy any thing unless I know where it comes from, and that all is right" - Smith then asked if there were any offered for sale on the Saturday night - he said, "No, I believe not; but I will ask my wife," and she said, "No"- the other officer then entered, and said, "We have got information that there is stolen property here, and we are come to search your house" - the prisoner said, "I see you are officers, you are welcome to search" - they went into the back room, picked up one pair of shoes, and asked me if I knew them - I said, "Yes" - Smith then asked the prisoner where he got them - he said he bought them in Petticoat-lane on the Friday, and gave 5s. for them - they kept on searching for about a quarter of an hour - when they came to the front room, where the prisoner's wife was sitting, in the corner, behind her chair, under a table covered with green baize, were these other two pairs - I can swear to them - they have my uncle's mark on them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is it not the custom of small shoemakers, when in distress, to sell shoes on Saturday nights to shops? A. It may be - Smith asked the prisoner if he had any shoes to sell - he did not offer to sell these - he said he had kept these for his own use, and he had worn one pair - he was liberated on bail, and has surrendered here - he made search for the person he bought them of, and had one person taken up.

Q. Was not that person's name Smith, and was he not a cousin of this very Smith the officer? A. No, he was not - the magistrate asked him that - he said he was not, but that he always called the policemen cousins and uncles - I do not know what his name was - these shoes hung on our door-post - a person might stand at the door and take them.

HENRY WEBB
(police-constable H 80). I produce the first pair of shoes that was found at the prisoner's - the other officer afterwards found the other two pair - when I got up to the door, Smith and the prosecutor were talking to the prisoner - Smith said, "Were any shoes sold here on Saturday night?" - the prisoner said, "No" - Smith then asked if any were offered him; he said, "No, not to me, but I will ask my old woman" - he turned to his wife, and said, "Were any shoes offered?" she said, "No" - I said,"I have information that some are here which are stolen" - he said, "I have no objection at all to your searching;" and under the bed I found this pair.

Cross-examined. Q. Was this the first thing that happened? A. When I went up, the prisoner and Smith and the prosecutor were in conversation - we had been waiting at a distance - we thought if we had gone in at first, he would have made away with them, most likely - there were three men in the house, and the prisoner's wife, who would very likely have assisted her husband to get out of trouble.

Q. Do you know the boy who was taken up by the prisoner after he was bailed? A. I had seen him about four months ago - I had spoken to him - he gave his name as Peacock - I do not know how long Peacock had known Smith - he said he was related to one of the officers - I should not like to state who gave me the information - I did not receive it from the prosecutor - I received it from a person who was afterwards charged.

Q. Upon your oath, from the same source that you derived intelligence that the shoes were in the prisoner's house, did you not know who the thief was? A. No; he did not tell me who stole them - he said they were sold at that house, and he was along with the party who sold them- it was Peacock told me.
Q. Was not Peacock charged before the magistrate with stealing them? A. No; he was taken up for being in company with the person who sold them.

COURT. Q. Do you say he was charged in the presence of the magistrate with being the person who sold the shoes? A. Peacock said, in the presence of the magistrate, that he in company with the person who sold them.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. And the magistrate discharged him? A. Yes - Mr. Broughton was the magistrate - Peacock saidhe was with the person that sold them, but he did not sell them, and the prisoner said the same.
COURT. Q. I want to know how it was that Peacock was discharged? A. The magistrate said he did not blame the solicitor to want to get out of a bad case.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long had you known this Mr. Peacock, who admits being with the person who sold them? A. Four months - I have seen him, and spoken to him, perhaps a dozen times - he never gave me information before, I knew he lived in Wentworth-street - I do not know the number - he came to me voluntarily on my beat and told me.
COURT. Q. What is Peacock? A. In my opinion, he is a thief - I told the magistrate I had seen him in company with thieves - I said that before Mr. Wooller put the question to me.

Q. Do you mean on your oath to say that Peacock was charged with stealing these shoes, admitted he was with the man who sold them on the very night they were stolen, and you told Mr. Broughton you had seen him in company with thieves, and he discharged him? A. Yes - the magistrate said it was very unusual for the thief to tell of himself- it was during the last month that I was on duty in Wentworth-street, that I had a thorough knowledge of Peacock.

JAMES SMITH
(police-constable H 122). On the 28th of July, I went to the prisoner - I saw him at his door - I asked if he had a pair of shoes to fit me - he handed me down some second-hand shoes - I said they were not good enough, and if he had any better I would thank him to show me them - he said he had none - I said, "Have you no new ones?" - he said, "No" - I said, "Did you get no new ones on Saturday night?" - he said, "No" - I said,"I have been informed you bought some stolen ones on Saturday night?" - he said, "No; we do not do business in that way - we know who we buy of" - my brother officer then came up, and went into the back room - he found one pair of shoes under the bed - nothing more transpired for a good while, till I found these two pair of shoes under the table in the front room - they were concealed.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you mean? A. There was a dish cover between the sight of persons and them, and there was a green baize over the table - I asked him if he had any shoes to sell - Webb gave me information of this- I believe I know the person who informed Webb - I have no doubt I do - I do not know that any one was taken up for stealing these shoes - I have not heard it - there was a person taken up for being with the person who sold them.

Q. Then the person taken up was not charged with being the thief? A. I believe that was the charged he was brought on - I believe his name is Peacock - I never saw him till the evening we got information - I believe he has claimed to be my cousin, but not in my presence - I heard he had not been a very good character, but had not been in prison.
Q. Has he not been a reputed thief, and as such suffered to go at large by the police? A. No.

Prisoner's Defence. On the Saturday night, about half-past ten o'clock, two persons brought these shoes to my house, and asked 15s. for them - I said it was too much, and they agreed to take 12s. - on Monday morning, Smith asked if I had any shoes to sell - I said, "No," as I meant to keep them for myself - when the officers came, I said they were welcome to search, as I had done nothing I was afraid of - they found these shoes, but they were not at all concealed.

JAMES HUTCHINSON
. I lodge at the prisoner's - on Saturday night, the 26th of July, two young men brought these three pair of shoes - they spoke to me first - I called the prisoner, and he bought them in my presence - they asked 15s. for them - he offered them 12s., and they took it- there was no concealment of them.
NOT GUILTY .

1464.
ALEXANDER COUSINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 65lbs. of lead, value 9s.; the goods of
Isaac Solly
and others, and fixed to a building , against the Statute, &c.

Two other counts stating it to belong to
William Lowe Wheeler
and
Elizabeth Deeble
.
The Prosecution was conducted by Mr. BODKIN.

CHARLES CLIFT
. I am secretary to the small-pox hospital
- Mr. Isaac Solly is one of the trustee s, and there are others - I have a deed which conveys the building and its appurtenances to Mr. Solly and others, in fee.

THOMAS HARVEY
. I am apprentice to Mr. Soward, a plumber and glazier - he was employed to do some repairs at the small-pox hospital - the prisoner was his journeyman - I went with him on the 27th of August - he cleared out the cistern, and then I got a flannel and assisted him - he then proceeded to cut the lead out of it - as he cut the pieces of lead, he gave them to me, as I was standing on the ladder, for me to throw down, which I did - this was in the afternoon, and after I had thrown down the lead, I observed the prisoner's waistcoat was open, and he appeared bulky round the body - his shirt was up - he had sent me away four or five times, and I was gone three or four minutes - we left there about half-past five, and went to the corner of Liverpool-street - he then gave me the tools, and told me to wait - he said he should not be above two or three minutes - he went up Manchester-street, towards Gray's-inn-road - I did not see him go into any house, but I saw him come out of Mr. Clark's, which is about a dozen doors from where he left me - he then came and told me to go back to the hospital for some plugs - I went and brought them, and then we parted - I noticed his person looked bulky while he was walking.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he look like a man who had 60lbs. of lead? A. He looked rather bulky in front of his stomach - I went into the cistern two or three times - I was not in it when he cut the lead.

Q. Did you ever say you were not in the cistern at all? A. No; I was not at the time he was in it - I might have said it - I was in the cistern two or three times - I did not cut the lead in the cistern - I cut the waste pipe - I have a brother-in-law, who is employed at Drury-lane theatre, and I sometimes went to assist him before I went to Mr. Soward - I did not go to any other theatre - I was in the employ of a Mr. Duncan - I have travelled to Bath - I was in the service of an umbrella-maker - I did not say any thing to the prisoner when I saw his waistcoat open - I thought it might be heat - I was not taken up myself - I told Mr. Soward the next morning when he asked me, and showed him where we had been.

WILLIAM BROWN EDWARDS
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. On the 29th of August, I went to Mr. Clack, No. 77, Manchester-street, and found the lead here produced- I then went to the hospital, and looked at the cistern, and the other pieces of lead - I put the other pieces of lead with these, and they completely from the bottom of the cistern - I have no doubt these are part of it - I found this belt under the prisoner's waistcoat - it has the appearance of having carried lead.

JOHN SOWARD
. I am the superintendant of the works- the prisoner was in my brother's employ, who is a plumber- this lead and what was left formed the bottom of the cistern.

CHARLES CLACK
. I am brother of Mr. Clack, who lives at No. 77, Manchester-street - I was at home on the 27th of August, and he was out - the prisoner brought this lead about six or seven o'clock - I did not know him then - he asked me if Mr. Clack was at home - I told him no, but he could leave the lead till Mr. Clack came home if he liked - I weighed it - there was half a hundered weight and seven pound - he came the next morning, and brought two or three bits more, which he said he had forgotten - Mr. Clack was at home then, but he was not up, and the prisoner was to come again in the evening, but did not.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever say you did not know who the man was? A. I could not describe him to Mr. Clack - the prisoner rang the bell, and I went up stairs - he was in the shop then - I was up in half a minute - I do not know whether a man could have unrolled this lead from his body before I got up, but it was on the bench when I got up - it was rolled up - my brother was taken up - I cannot tell whether I stated that the prisoner was the man before my brother was taken up - I had not known the prisoner before - I had no suspicion of any thing being wrong - the lead was taken into our vault - I parted it into two lots, and wrapped it up in some new bits of our own.
JURY. Q. You found the lead on the bench, and the prisoner in the shop, when you went up stairs - where did he then go? A. Down stairs to our lower shop, and when he left, he went up the area steps.
Witnesses for the Defence.

SUSANNAH SPRINGETT
. I am a widow, and I live at the hospital - I saw the prisoner and Harvey both in the cistern together on the day stated, and I gave them a pint of beer to drink in the cistern.
COURT. Q. Did they ask you to give them beer? A. No; I asked if they would like another pint - Harvey came out of the cistern, and took it of me - they were both down inside the cistern.

JOHN PILLING
. I am a carpenter. I was at work at the hospital - I saw the prisoner going away - I did not observe any thing particular about him - I saw Harvey come back again, and carry away a bag or a parcel between his arms.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Do not you know that plumbers have a bag to carry tools in? A. Yes; it was something of that kind.

GEORGE PITKIN
. I am a carpenter, and was at work there. I saw the prisoner go away - I saw nothing more than ordinary about him - within eight or ten minutes of his leaving, Mr. Wheeler had ordered us some beer, and the prisoner drank some of it.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Had he not a bag? A. I believe he had some tools - I did not notice whether he had a bag.

(
William Ellard
, a plumber, of Windmill-street;
Thomas Gilderway
, a builder, South Molton-street;
William Davis
, plumber, Warwick-street;
Stephen Hayes
, Edward-street, City-road; and
Richard Nixon
, a plumber, of Warwick-lane, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 25. - Recommended to mercy . -
Confined One Year .

1465.
MARY VARLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 19 handkerchiefs, value 4l. 15s.; 9 pair of stockings, value 3l.; 24 pair of cotton stockings, value 1l. 16s.; 16 shirts, value 5l.; 12 towels, value 4s.; 6 night shirts, value 12s.; 1 dressing coat, value 18s.; and 1 night cap, value 9s. ; the goods of
Ann Porter
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the Prosecution.

ANN PORTER. I am a widow , and keep an outfitting warehouse , at Charing-cross
. In July last, the prisoner came and said she had recommended my house to old Mr. and Mrs. Varley, her husband's father and mother - that they wanted a great many things; and first, they would have some silk handkerchiefs and stockings to choose from- I had my bonnet on, and was going out - I told my young woman to show the handkerchiefs - she said they were to be shown to Mr. and Mrs. Varley, and to be returned if not approved - she came several times, and at last I began to have some suspicion.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Has not she been in the habit of dealing at your house for some years? A. Yes; since October, 1831 - either she or her husband paid for the goods she had - she asked for the running credit of twelve months, which she had, and paid soon after Christmas, but it was of small amount - we entered the goods she had in the waste book, which is here - I entered these goods to Mrs. Varley, but supposing it was for old Mrs. Varley - this entry was similar to the previous entries - I made out a bill of parcels to Mrs. Varley - I did not write"Old Mrs. Varley's."

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Would you have let her have these things for herself? A. No, not in any way; her entries before this were not more than 8l. in a year - I knew old Mr. and Mrs. Varley by report, and one of the parcels was directed to Pangbourn, near Reading.

ELIZA GUY
. I was in the prosecutrix's shop when the prisoner came for these things - I heard her say she had recommended Mrs. Porter to Mr. Varley, of Pangbourn, and she wished to have some handkerchiefs and other things - Mrs. Porter was going out, and I made up the order - I offered to send it, but she took it away herself - the goods were to be taken back or exchanged, if not approved by old Mr. and Mrs. Varley - the next day, she came again - she said two of the silk handkerchiefs were not approved of, and she looked out seven others - she wanted some more of the stockings, but we had none - she came again, and went on dealing, till the bill came to 25l.
Cross-examined. Q. You entered the goods to Mrs. Varley? A. Yes, as we had before; and I gave her a memorandum of them, as she said they would want to know the price - I knew they were not for her.

MR.
JOHN BENJAMIN VARLEY
. I am the prisoner's husband's father - I never commissioned her to buy goods for me or my wife - I never saw her till she was at Bow-street.

MRS.
MARTHA VARLEY
. I never commissioned the prisoner to buy any goods - I never received any.

THOMAS BIRKETT
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker- I have some silk stockings and handkerchiefs, pawned on the 23rd of July, for 32s., by a female - I cannot say it was the prisoner.

HENRY FALL
. I took the prisoner, and found on her the duplicate of these goods.

THOMAS BEIK WALTER
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce some stockings, and other things, pawned by the prisoner; one lot on the 26th of July, for 3l.; and one lot on the 30th of July, for 5l.

JAMES MOTT
. I am a pawnbroker. I have seven handkerchiefs, and six pairs of silk stockings, pawned by the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. My husband's disgraceful conduct was the cause of my pawning these things - I was privately married to him, but his conduct in going with other females was such that I could not live with him - the man Varley, now in Court, persuaded his son to abscond and leave me destitute; and, on my demanding a maintenance, he promised, on my retiring into Wales, to allow me the vast sum of 20l. a year - I went there; but on my applying to a bank, through which it was to be remitted, he, to my great surprise, refused this 20l. a year, pretending it was not due - my friends then persuaded me to return, and reside near his country seat, till he felt inclined to perform his promise, and send me this handsome settlement of 20l. a year - I went and resided at a little cottage, near his country seat - but finding he would do nothing for me, I went to Mrs. Porter, who let me have the things; but as she had given me twelve months' credit before, I thought I should have time to pay her - I thought, as I had the good had a right to do what I pleased with them - my chief prosecutor would not send me what he promised, though his son got in debt with other women, and it was all laid on my shoulders; and so destitute has my husband left me, that when I go out, I should not know where to turn for a home, nor where to go for a sixpence.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Nine Months .

1466.
MARY ANN CAPONE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 2 decanters, value 16s.; 6 drinking glasses, value 5s.; 3 pair of trowsers, value 20s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; 4 spoons, value 20s.; 4 shirts, value 18s.; 5 sheets, value 16s.; 3 table-cloths, value 18s.; 1 counterpane, value 8s.; 2 toilette covers, value 6s.; and 2 handkerchiefs, value 7s.; the goods of
George Newland
, her master .

GEORGE NEWLAND
. The prisoner was in my service, and left on the 7th of August - I then missed these articles.

GEORGE FREDERICK SHEPHERD
. I am a pawnbroker - I produce these articles, which were pawned by the prisoner, between the 7th of May and the 7th of August.
Prisoner. The prosecutor said, if the duplicates were delivered up, he would not proceed against me.
GEORGE NEWLAND. I said so, but I had only missed three spoons then.

ELIZA RYLAND
. I am the prisoner's sister - I went to the prosecutor, and his man said if the duplicates were given up, he would not hurt a hair of her head.
NOT GUILTY .

1467.
GEORGE ANSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 hat, value 4s.; and two gloves, value 1s. ; the goods of
Frederick Bennell
.

FREDERICK BENNELL. I am a law stationer - on the 29th of July I was at the Bedford Arms
, playing at skittles - I then went into the billiard-room, leaving my hat and gloves in the skittle ground - the prisoner was afterwards taken with them.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is the skittle ground covered? A. The floor of the billiard room covers it - I went up stairs without my hat - all the lights were put out but one.

GEORGE BROWN
. I was at the skittle ground - I did not see the prosecutor put his hat down - I did not tell the magistrate that I did, but I saw the prisoner take a white hat, and try to put it inside his own, but he could not - he then put his own hat on, and put the white hat under the front of his coat - I pursued him with a friend - I said to him, "Young man, it is no use your attempting to make off with that hat; I know what you have got" - he said, "It is nothing but a boy's hat" - I said, "It belongs to a gentleman in the Bedford Arms, you had better take it back" - he said he would not - we went about one hundred yards further, and one of the young men who was with him said,"If you take it back, you are a b - y fool" - the prisoner said he would take it back, provided one of his own party would go back with him - a policeman came by, and I gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. You were looking at him when he was putting the hat under his own? A. Yes, I was looking at him - Matthews saw it - I did not call out, "You have got a white topper" - I do not know what it means.

DANIEL MADDEN
(police-constable S 186). I took the prisoner with the hat - I heard the witness say, "I insist upon the gloves being returned to the owner" - I found the gloves in his pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. The hat was thrown at me - I walked about one hundred yards - the witness came, and said it was a gentleman's hat - I then said I would take it back, but he wanted to take it back himself.

JAMES MATTHEWS
. I am a wheelwright - I was there that night - these gentlemen came in - they asked me to get them a light, and set up their skittles, which I did - we then went out - Brown came after us and said, "You have got a white topper;" and he said he would take it back - but the prisoner said he would.
NOT GUILTY .

1468.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 salt-cellar, value 2s. 6d.; 1 spoon, value 5s.; and 1 knife, value 9d. ; the goods of
Richard King
.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I am servant to Mr. Richard King - he resides at Hornsey
- I was working in the field at two o'clock in the afternoon on the 7th of July - I saw the prisoner looking in at Mr. King's parlour window, and before I could get round the stable yard he had walked into theparlour - I went to him, and asked what business he had there - he said to see if any one was there - I said I would have him taken - he took these things out of his pocket, and gave them to me - they are my master's.

GUILTY . Aged 61. -
Confined Six Months .

1469.
EDWARD EVANS
and
WILLIAM WOOD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 key, value 3d.; 1 trowel, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of slippers, value 1s.; the goods of
Richard Chalener
; and 3 locks, value 3s.; 4 finger-plates, value 1s. 6d.; and 2 brass knobs, value 6d.; the goods of the said Richard Chalener, then fixed to a building , against the Statute.

RICHARD CHALENER. I live at No. 23, Grafton-street
- the house is under repair - these are my articles, and were fixed to the building - I missed them at five o'clock in the morning, on Monday week.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you mean they were all fixed to the building? A. These locks and plates and knobs were - I have fitted them to their places, and they correspond exactly.

HENRY ALDERSON
(police-constable C 164). On the 2nd of September I was on duty in Grafton-street - I heard a noise at No. 23 - I went over, and the gentleman at No. 22 looked out, as he had heard a noise - I waited till Bishop came up - we went into No. 22, and got into No. 23 - we heard some persons run up stairs, and we went up- I saw a hand taking a ladder through a trap door at the top - I jumped up, caught the ladder, and went up - I found the trap door of No. 24 was open - I went in, and found Evans in bed, with his stockings and drawers on, and Wood was on a bed on the floor - there was some lime on his shirt, and on the bed likewise - I found a bunch of keys on the table, and a knife - Bishop and I desired them to get up, and they were taken to the station-house - I went back to No. 23, and found a sack, with these things in it, on the roof - there was a puddle of water on the roof, and I found wet marks in the room where the prisoners were - Wood's shoes were wet.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you find Evans's shoes? A. No; Wood was in his shirt; but it was some minutes after I tapped at the door before it was opened - I did not examine Evans's feet, but his hands were dirty - there were some women on the stairs of No. 24.

HUGH BISHOP
. I am an officer. I went in with Alderson - I saw some persons go into No. 24 - we got down, and tracked them by some lime - we knocked at a room door, but it was five minutes before we got admission - I heard some bustling inside - Wood was on an old piece of bed on a blanket, and Evans was in bed - I asked him how long he had been in bed - he said about two o'clock - I took him to the station-house, and in going along he threw this knob down an area - I found some of these things on Evans, under his shirt - this key fits one of the locks, which was found on the premises.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you tell the magistrate you heard a hustling in the room? A. Yes; I cannot tell whether that is in the deposition - I only saw one woman in the house, who appeared to live there - I went into the next room - I did not look at Evans's shoes - he took them from under the bed, and put them on - this lantern was burning on the roof.
Evans's Defence. I have got locks to fit these keys.
Wood's Defence. I was sitting smoking with Evans.

(
Alfred Dixon
, a saddle-maker, of Short's gardens; and
Alfred Watson
, a publican, gave Wood a good character;
Thomas Hacket
, a broker, of Gould-square;
Thomas Coxworthy
, Westminster Bridge-road;
William Ashman
, and
Bernice Grant
, gave Evans a good character.)

EVANS -
GUILTY . Aged 51.

WOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 56.

Recommended to mercy -
Transported for Seven Years .

1470.
THOMAS SUTHERLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 1 saddle, value 3l.; 1 bridle, value 4s.; and 1 horse-cloth, value 20s. ; the goods of
John Tilbury
.

NEWCOMB MASON
. I am an assistant to Mr. Tilbury, of Mount-street, Grosvenor-square
- I missed a great many saddles, bridles, and horse cloths - I was passing Mr. Langdon's shop last Wednesday, and saw this horse cloth, which I knew was my master's - I then traced it to the prisoner - the saddle was found at Lambeth - the prisoner had been a helper in the stable , but left nearly three months ago.

WILLIAM LANGDON
. I am a saddler. I bought the saddle and horse-cloth for 2l. 10s., of Marrs, whom I have known eight years.

EDWARD MARRS
. I sold the saddle, horse-cloth, and this snap-bridle to Langdon - Riggs brought them into Mr. Jackson's yard, where I was at work - I did not know Riggs, but I came into the yard, and one of our men said,"Here is something to be sold, do you know a man that will buy them?" - I said, "Yes, if it is all right" - I took and sold them, and paid Riggs 30s., which was what he asked.

THOMAS RIGGS
. One night, a fortnight before this, I met the prisoner at the corner of Duke-street - he asked if I was doing any thing - I said, "No;" he told me to go to him the next morning - I did so, and we went to a house, and had a pint of beer - he then said he had these things to sell for his brother, who was going out of town with a gentleman - I asked him if it was all right; he said it was - I took them to Mr. Jackson, and gave them to the ostler, who gave them to Marrs - I went back and asked the prisoner if it was all right; he said he would not have any thing to do with it without it was.

Prisoner's Defence. I found them in the Swan passage, near Mr. Tilbury's - I gave them to Riggs to sell - he came back, and said he had sold them for 26s. - he gave me 25s. and we spent 1s. - I gave him 4s. for his trouble.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Nine Months .

1471.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 2 carriage-lamps, value 20s. , the goods of
Thomas Ellis
.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS
. I am in the employ of Mr. Thomas Ellis - he is a coach-maker - the prisoner formerly worked for him. On the 1st of September I saw the prisoner in the shop standing by a Stanhope - I saw him takethe two lamps out - he put one under his arm, and carried the other down by his side - I pursued him, called the policeman, and gave him into custody.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 43. -
Confined Ten Days .

1472.
GEORGE FRANCIS
and
MATILDA FRANCIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 chaise, value 1l. , the goods of
John Allen
.

JOHN ALLEN, jun.
I am the son of John Allen, of Hackney-road
. Matilda Francis came on the 20th of August, I let her a child's chaise at 2d. an hour - I am sure she is the person - she never brought it back - this is it.

GEORGE KEMP
(police-constable N 82). I found this chaise at Mr. Gurney's - Matilda Francis was given to me first - she said her brother gave her 2d. to go and get the chaise, and he then took it from her - I then took George Francis - he said he would tell the truth, and he took us to Mr. Gurney's.

GEORGE GURNEY
. I live at No. 1, Middle-row, Goswell-street. This chaise was brought to me by a girl and boy, but I believe not the prisoners - they said they had no mother, and their father was ill in bed - I said I would go to him, and they ran away - I kept the chaise for two days, and intended to advertise it, but the officer came and had it.
NOT GUILTY .

1473.
GEORGE FRANCIS
and
MATILDA FRANCIS
were again indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 chaise, value 30s. , the goods of
John Corben
.

JEMIMA AUSTIN
. The prisoner, George Francis, came to me on the 14th of August, and asked me to hire a chaise- he said if I did, the baby I had in my arms should ride - he went with me as far as Mr. Corben's door - he put 2d. into my hand, and said, "Mind you have the chaise that I point out" - I hired the chaise, put my baby into it, and went to Pancras fields - he then told me to take my baby out, and he would put his sister in - he then ran away with it.

SUSAN CORBEN
. I am the wife of John Corben. Austin hired the chaise of me - it has not been found.

GEORGE KEMP
, When I took the prisoner, he said he got a chaise from this shop, and sold it for 3s. 6d.; but I could not find where - he sent me to one place, but that was not right.

GEORGE FRANCIS - GUILTY. Aged 11.
Judgment Respited
.
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

MATILDA FRANCIS -
NOT GUILTY .

1474.
GEORGE OAKLEY
was indicted for a
misdemeanour .

FRANCIS COURTNEY
. I am a cheesemonger , and live at the corner of Clare-court, Drury-lane
. The prisoner had lived in my employ - on the morning of the 15th of July, I heard a noise - I heard some one jump as if from the landing, and I heard footsteps - I opened the window, and saw the officer with the prisoner in his arms - my windows had all been shut the last thing the night before - there was a cupboard in the kitchen - I had fastened the door of it, and in the morning I found the cupboard door open, and some spoons were at the edge of the shelf, which were not there the night before - it was clear some one had broken in.

WILLIAM WILCOX
. I live in Drury-lane. I heard a noise, and looked out at my window that morning - I saw the blinds of Mr. Courtney's first-floor window were flying about, and I saw a person on his hands and knees on the leads, pushing up the window to get in - I called the officer.

EDMUND SWEENEY
(police-constable F 130.) I was on duty, and heard an alarm - I ran, and saw some persons at the corner of Clare-court - the prisoner was running round on the leads, and trying to make his escape, and I took him.
Prisoner. I was inebriated. Witness. No; he was not.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined for Nine Months .
(See page 637.)
